The Pine Creek Rail Trail runs through Pine Creek Gorge aka the "Grand Canyon of PA." The region certainly lives up to its name, as Pine Creek has carved steep slopes from the Pennsylvania landscape over millennia.  Today, the gorge is a beautiful and scenic locale. 

A long logging history once stripped this beautiful area of the ancient hardwood and pine forests that had thrived for centuries, though more recent protections from the National Parks Service and the Pennsylvania State Forest Service have made a great impact on the damage of the area. Today, 100-year-old trees and a variety of local fauna have returned to the gorge, providing for scenic company to any taking the rail trail. The recovery of the area is a testament to the resiliency of our natural world. 

The trail itself is well maintained, and is mostly composed of hard packed dirt or crushed limestone. While most visitors use one of two main trailheads, there are many access points on this trail, making it easy to plan an outing of almost any distance. For those seeking a longer outing, there are many places to camp along the trail and the scenery is amazing. You won't be disappointed by taking this great trail!
Park at Lot #4 on the Rim Road. Roots and rocks abound.

This trail doesn't have a lot of elevation gain, but what there is can be a little steep. There are lots of loose rocks throughout, and a few more rugged sections, mostly around creek crossings in the bottom of the ravines.

To access this trail, park at the Urey Overlook parking lot, which is at top of the hill upriver from Otter Creek.  

Cross PA425 and follow the blue-blazed Mason-Dixon Trail to where it turns left. Go straight on the red-blazed trail to Otter Creek. Turn left and follow the blue/red-blazed trail down the creek. When the blue-blazed trail turns left, continue on the red-blazed trail. 

At mile 1.4, follow the red-blazed trail to where the blue-blazed trail comes back down the hill. Continue straight ahead on the blue/red-blazed trail. At mile 2.8, down near the mouth of the creek, an orange-blazed trail comes in from the left. Continue on the red-blazed trail down to PA425.  

Cross PA425 and find a yellow-blazed trail that goes down the embankment. Follow the yellow blazes until you connect back to the blue blazes. At mile 4.0, turn right on the blue blazes and follow the blue blazes up the hill to
Urey Overlook. Enjoy the views!  

After enjoying the view at Urey Overlook, leave the overlook and turn right. Follow the blue blazes on an old logging road back to your vehicle.

A small parking area is available where the Appalachian Trail crosses 873. Additional parking is available across the Lehigh at the A.T. parking lot, and at the Lehigh Gap Nature Center. It's a steep climb up the Appalachian Trail southbound to reach the North trail. Another option is to go up Translator Lane off Mountain Road. It ends at the top of the mountain near the cell and radio towers. BUT, if you don't have a 4WD with high clearance, park in the parking lot just off Mountain Road and walk up.

As of 2015, this was one of two officially blazed trails in a park; it featured a little more than 6 miles of steep singletrack.  The trail climbs steeply up Girl Scout Hill to the Buffalo enclosure. The county rangers, have removed the majority of the white blazes in preparation to blaze the Paul Riis trail that will connect the unique stone features in the park with white blazes.  

The old  Trailhead is behind the stop sign at the bottom of the VIP/Ice Skating Rink Lot.  The Trail follows the stream, Catfish Run, to the Girl Scout Cabin Field.  When you come into the clearing, follow the trail to the cabin and turn around before it reenters the woods.  

About 75 yards into the woods, make a hard left up out of the valley floor.  Near the top, make a left at the fork in the trail.  Once you reach the parking lot, make a left. After about 100 yards, make another left and proceed down almost all the way to Corrigan Dr.  Near the bottom, be sure to make a right and follow the trail to McConkey Rd.  Cross McConkey Rd at the light and follow the trail, which parallels Corrigan Dr, until it makes a hard right on its way up to the top of the Buffalo enclosure.  

At the top of the hill, the trail opens into a gravel parking lot.  You'll see the trail heading towards the Buffalo enclosure.  Follow the fence line before reentering the woods.  Cross Sesqui Dr and make a left onto the current Montour Trail extension down to Corrigan Rd.  

Cross Corrigan Rd and make a right turn to Cricket Field Parking Lot.  To the right of the basketball hoops, the trail opens and starts again. Follow it past the Cricket field and up to the exercise path. Continue straight up to, and cross, Maple Spring Dr at the break in the guard rail.  

Climbing toward the golf course, the trail crosses a service road and drops into the woods in the gravel pull off.  Follow it down to the Oliver Miller Homestead and cross Stone Manse Dr.  The white blazes will take you up along the golf course before dropping you down to East Park Dr. 

At the bottom of the hill, you'll cross East Park Dr and drop down to the stream. Cross the bridge and bear left.  Follow the white blazes to the water fountain and proceed uphill below the old shelter.  The last section of trail parallels Corrigan Dr. before it drops you down to the intersection of 100 Acres Dr. and Corrigan Dr.  The VIP/Ice Skating rink lot will be across the street.

The trail heads south from the AT Appalachian Trail and climbs steeply up the northern slope of Little Rocky Ridge. At the ridge line, a short spur leads east to the Sunset Rocks with great views south over the South Mountain highlands. The trail proceeds west along the narrow spine of the ridge in an open rock scramble before descending to Michaux Rd. The trail then proceeds west along the base of Big Hill and rejoins the AT Appalachian Trail just south of Tom's Run Shelter.

The Allegheny Front Trail starts at the PA 504 trailhead, circumnavigating the State Park in a clockwise direction, starting at the "3 o'clock" position, with yellow blazes painting all 41 miles of the trail. There are signs at any tricky intersections, so navigation is not an issue the majority of the time. 

Most fast running springs are great for drinking, provided that they are properly filtered. DO NOT drink the Moshannon Creek water. Its orange color is a result of coal mining, and it is not suitable for drinking. 

Campsites are plentiful, with one every five miles or so, if not even closer together.

The Highland Trail cuts across the top of the Falls Trail System and crosses through Midway Crevasse, a narrow passageway between large blocks of Pocono sandstone conglomerates that were deposited throughout this area by glacial movements. The Highland Trail connects the two northern sections of the Falls Trail System. At least three times in the last one million years, continental glaciers buried this land under hundreds of feet of ice. This trail makes an excellent area for geological study groups.

The major highlight of this trail is Midway Crevasse where hikers need to walk single file through the opening in the rock. This unusual rock feature is in stark contrast from the majority of this trail's features.
Land Manager:  Lancaster Conservancy

The trail is challenging and steep, but the reward is two viewspoints. The second view is breathtaking.

At the parking lot near the bridge, there is an information board and a sign for Falls Trail. The trail starts here. Go down the stone stairs, turn right and go under the bridge. Follow the trail to another information board. Most hikers go straight to waterfalls. You turn right and follow red markers. 

Soon the trail climbs up the stone steps and progressively gets harder.  At 0.6 miles you'll pass the shortcut trail to the top of waterfalls. At 0.8 miles you'll see first overlook. Once you enjoy the view, turn around and you'll see a huge stone. In front of this stone, there is an unmarked trail. Take this trail for another 0.6 miles to the next perfect 180 degrees view. The view is worth every effort.
Mid State Trail (MST)

Accessible from the spillway parking lot or from the western terminus of Appaloosa Trail, this 9 mile singletrack gives constant cover of trees from summer sun, while taking hikers through constant ups and downs at no more than 10% grade.

The trail makes several stream crossings and follows along two for short stretches, making the trail muddy at times.  There are definitely roots along the trail but, for the most part, the trail is a good ~9-mile point-to-point for all levels of hiker.

Starting from the mineral springs parking lot, make an immediate right after crossing over the stream using the bridge.  This will take you along route 18 crossing the stream and through a marshy area before a u-turn which heads up the hill side.

This section has pockets of pines which offer soft trail and a change of scenery.  Midway through you'll come to a fork in the trail, head left to stay on trail (this is marked with a sign).  Emerging from the woods, you'll cross over Heritage Trail and head down a cliff side via stairs, taking you to the waterfall.  This section is slippery, given it resides in the stream bed, but is unique in that sense.

It’s hard to find hiking paths in Central PA that aren’t extremely rocky. This trail is soft underfoot and completely shaded by trees in the late spring and summer. There’s a main creek with a few smaller runs. The trail that’s mapped is the main loop but there are other detours and opportunities for exploring in Speedwell Forge County Park.

Access the trail from the Greer Road or at the Calumet shelter near the entrance to the park.  You make an initial very short climb from the parking lot and at the "peak" will see a sign signifying the highest point in the park at around 1,250 feet.  

The trail then heads downhill, crosses a road, and brings hikers to a "Y" in the trail.  Take the Lake Loop to the right.  The Lake Loop is identified by a simple wooden sign on a tree.  Staying right will take you to Greer Road.  In half a mile, you'll come out to the small lake/pond.  At the other end of the lake, you'll make a sharp left up the hill climbing 100 feet or so before leveling out and making your descent to Greer Road.  

The trail is smooth with a few sections with mud or roots.  The climbs and descents are steep and one section has loose rock, but in general it is a good trail for a hike.  

You'll have access to plenty of other unknown trails, but they don't all loop back, so you may want to study up at the park website or use the Hiking Project mobile app.
Mid State Trail (MST)

Perhaps the steepest trail in the entire park, the Round Top Trail takes you up to the top of Round Top Hill and back down the other side. Many switchbacks make up most of this trail and the trip to the top is fun.  A park bench at the top of the trail will greet you for a much-needed breather.

Park at the Sugarloaf Sledding Hill/Snowmobile/MTB parking lot and pick up the trail heading down the mountain parallel to the road.  Eventually, you'll cross the road and continue on the opposite side, there will be a few uphills here eventually leading to the Baughman Rock Overlook. From the overlook you'll want to continue down the mountain into town.

For a great loop, hike up Sugarloaf Trail from town, cross Sugarloaf Road, and descend to Ohiopyle.

The trailhead is located at the parking lot for the bike shop. As is the case for North Country Trail, the blaze is bright blue. In general, the trail is well-groomed, but there are sections of loose rock and larger rocks that slow your pace.

The trail starts by taking you over Hidden River Bridge before crossing the bike path and N. Shore Drive. Once over the road, you start the first of many climbs. Continue following the blazes over several roads, around one small pond, and past the marina on your way to the end of this section at Route 528, near the bridge crossing over Lake Arthur.

Once you cross Route 528, you'll be presented with a 300-foot climb to the top of a ridge, which offers a nice view of Lake Arthur in fall and winter when the leaves have dropped. There are several stretches of open space as you climb which also give glimpses of the lake.

The next 5 miles are similar to the first 8. You'll make 3 climbs along singletrack trail which is primarily smooth with occasional sections of loose rock.

You'll recognize the end of the trail when you reach the Jennings Environmental Center and a uphill slope of flower beds. The end of the Glacier Ridge Trail does not mark the end of the North Country Trail, which continues on to Allegheny National Forest, and all the way to the New England states.

While the Blue Blaze Trail is one of the more arduous trails in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, the opportunities for striking views along the way make it all worthwhile. 

Starting at the summit of Mount Tammany, near the end of the Red Dot Trail, wander along the forested bluffs of Mount Tammany for a half-mile, before turning northwest and beginning a considerable descent through beautiful hardwood forests. During the fall and winter, watch your step as the descent can often be covered in slippery, wet leaves. 

After a mile of descending, the trail grades soften, allowing visitors to fully enjoy nearby Dunnfield Creek. At the junction with the Appalachian Trail (AT), continue south, following the trail downhill toward the parking area.

Grove Run is a loop that in either direction it is the steepest and most technically challenging descent and climb at Laurel Highlands.

Counter-clockwise: From the end of Fish Run, make a right. You'll be in for a very rocky, but manageable descent. On your way down you'll cross over Quarry Rd and eventually end up in Linn Run Campground. Make a left and follow the campground road to get the next section of Grove Run. This section will be a switchback climb that is rocky and narrow.  At the end of your 1.75 mile climb, you'll have a choice on how to return. You can go straight across Quarry Rd and make a right on Fish Run Tr to double back Fish Run or make a right on Quarry Rd, then a left on Weaver Rd and a left on Hickory Flats Rd to get to the top of Linn Run Rd. A right on Linn Run Rd will take you to Wolf Rocks Parking lot in less than a mile.

Clockwise: From the end of Fish Run a left is made on Grove Run. In less than 1/4 mile you cross over Quarry Rd. Be prepared for a rocky descent that will include tight switchbacks, rocky stream crossings and benchcut singletrack that is very narrow. After a 1.75 mile downhill you'll enter Linn Run Campground. Once in the campground you'll have to carefully watch for the continuation of Grove Run Trail on your right. When you find the trail, be prepared for a tough climb. Initially the rocks may make it challenging. After crossing Quarry Rd you'll hit uphill rocky sections, however, these are short lived. You'll eventually end the loop back at Fish Run Trail. From there you can make a left and double back Fish Run or go straight and make lefts on Quarry Rd, Weaver Rd and Hickory Flats Rd to get to the top of Linn Run Rd. A right on Linn Run Rd will take you to Wolf Rocks Parking lot in less than a mile.
Watch for poison ivy. Most of the trail is well marked with yellow blazes, however there are a lot of side trails so you need to watch carefully to stay on the main trail.

The Moss-Hanne Trail will lead visitors through the Black Moshannon Bog Natural Area. Along the way, hikers can expect to pass through woods, swamps, and marshes. This trail is frequently soggy, but sometimes provides boardwalks over particularly wet areas. 

Though the trail is rolling, it is not overly difficult, and there are very few obstacles to navigate around, soggy bits aside. This makes for a scenic tour of the Bog, and you'll enjoy being in the trees for most of the trail!

This trail takes you from the Weisel Hostel through a beautiful rocky forest consisting of deciduous and evergreen trees. There are excellent, elevated views of both the Tohickon Creek and Lake Nockamixon. The trail passes under the high bridge over 563 where fishermen often line the banks of the Tohickon Creek. At its end, the trail connects to the Sterner Mill Trail area.

trail_name: AT: Blue Mountain Eagle Climbing Club - West (PA)
description: Appalachian Trail (AT)

Typically you'll be approaching this trail from Whitetail Trail, for example in the Quebec Odyssey hike. Just before the final descent to the right on Pine Knob trail, take the left to check out the Pine Knob overlook. Then return to the descent to Lick Hollow Picnic area. The Lick Hollow Picnic area is nicely situated with ample parking and toilet. As an ascent from Picnic area its obviously more difficult, but definitely a worthwhile challenge.

The West Penn Trail is officially recognized as a National Recreation Trail and is a beautiful, accessible route for anyone in the area. The trail stretches between Saltsburg to just outside Blairsville along the path of the old Portage Railroad line that ran from 1830 to 1864. 

This line was originally built to connect Pittsburgh and Harrisburg. The trail is still under development in an effort to extend it further along the railroad path. For updated conditions and route information, check the Conemaugh Valley Conservancy website.

The trail is comprised of five sections. The first is at Conemaugh River Lake, near the Conemaugh Dam, where the trail heads across four stone arch bridges that date back to the early 1900s.

The second section is the Bow Ridge Switchback to Conemaugh Dam Section. Here, the trail passes two tunnels and a hydroelectric plant with some elevation that can be a great, aerobic challenge for riders.

The third section is the Dick Mayer section that follows the former railroad bed and has some challenging crushed gravel and rough, wooded singletrack. 

The penultimate section is Saltsburg and this stretch of the trail goes along the banks of the Conemaugh River for just over four miles, heading through shaded woodlands. Be aware as horseback riding and biking are permitted.

The final section is the Kiski Extension, which follows the east riverbank for 1.5 miles until it comes to an open field. Beyond the field, the trail heads onto private property.

Accessible from McKenna Trail and Painter Rock Trail (via a connector), the North Loop Trail is a rugged 5 mile loop with 1000 feet of climbing. There are three elements to this trail: jaggers, rocks/boulders, runs.  Going counterclockwise, the trail begins with a gentle descent, before turning straight down the mountainside at ~15-20% for a quarter mile, and then easing up again. The beginning section of trail, at roughly 2800 feet, is covered in knee-high grasses, similar to McKenna Trail. As you descend the trail, the grasses thin and vanish, before around 2200 feet, jaggers (briars) appear and thicken. This makes the trail a bit tougher to hike because the jaggers are large enough to cut up your legs. You may note a run crossing that cuts the trail diagonally. You'll cross this run later, when it is much larger and rushing downhill.

Around the first mile, the trail takes a significant turn left (south), but there appears to be other options.  Follow the yellow blazes. Very shortly after this turn, the trail makes another hard right, which is miss-able.  Small logs and sticks are dragged across the trail to mark the turn. If you stay straight the trail becomes noticeably less "maintained" and you'll not see any yellow blazes.

It is very shortly after these series of turns that you'll come to a brief section with boulders on either side of the trail and look like monuments. It's a nice reprieve from the jaggers and monotony of the trail.  

Once at the bottom of the mountain, the trail slowly begins rising. You'll cross two streams at this point. The first stream you'll have crossed earlier, and has grown as it picks up more water. The other stream originates within the loop. Roaring Run Natural Area contains several natural springs. Note the clarity of the water.

The final big turn marks the start of the 1000 foot climb. Unlike the descent, it is less steep and can be hike in many of the sections. There is a connector trail to take you to Painter Rock Trail about mid-way up the climb.

You'll arrive back at the loop start with McKenna Trail to the right.
Land Manager:  DNR - Fair Hill NRMA
Appalachian Trail (AT)

Both trailheads are found along the park road. The northern trailhead is tucked under trees with a small wooden bridge marking the entrance. The southern trailhead has a metal gate and looks like a fire access road. Once on the trail, it quickly turns to doubletrack mixed with singletrack. The trail has lots of smaller rocks and roots, but nothing notable.  

Starting at the southern trailhead, hikers climb the entire way to the 90-degree turn in the trail. The climb is gentle and the trail is smooth enough to make it very manageable. The turn marks the end of significant climbs; although there is a slight uphill, it is insignificant. Hikers will be able to see out ahead since the trail is so straight in this section and the tree canopy is high. At the end of the straight-away, hikers make another 90-degree turn, this time heading back down the hill paralleling Penny Run.

Once out of the woods, hikers can head to the campgrounds for the Nature Trail or Lowlands Trail or head towards the park office for some rugged singletrack on the north side of the lake (Adams Run, Orchard Trail, and Hunters Ridge).
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Fort Washington State Park

This trail begins at a point on the Elder's Run Trail very close to the game lands parking lot and follows middle creek up almost to the dam at the Middle Creek Reservoir. It connects with other trails along the way, including the Horseshoe Trail.

This longer loop of the Sunken Garden Trail begins along the shore of Lake Arthur in Moraine State Park.  The first 20 feet can be pretty muddy if it has rained recently. 

The trail is well-kept and begins along the lake where you can enjoy waterfowl and other types of birds.   There are several nesting boxes along the way as well. 

This trail has both a short and long loop. About 1/4 mile in you bump into the only significant incline but it can be a doozy for new hikers or the elderly.  

After the climb into the hillside, the scenery is close with no real vistas.   There are some great stands of pines that are definitely worth experiencing though.  

This is a loop trail and will return you to the parking area.

***IMPORTANT***  This trail is supposed to be marked with PINK blazes according to the state park map.  However, it has been remarked with DARK BLUE blazes.   The trail also appears to have undergone some redesigning.  There are some intersecting paths and offshoots but the blue blazes are easy to follow and well-marked.

This easy 3 mile trail follows the Schuylkill River from the River Trail parking lot off of Pawlings Road.  This parking area is next to the Pawlings Rd bridge over the Schuylkill.  If you are parked at the Pawlings Road Trail to the east and near 422, you are at the wrong spot. While similar in name, this trail is NOT the Schuylkill River Trail - Pawlings to Lock 60.

From the trailhead, follow the crushed gravel path down river 3 miles.  Along the way, you'll find several views of the Schuylkill River to your right.  You'll pass the site of Sullivan's Bridge, part of the Valley Forge encampment, where George Washington's Army took shelter during the winter of 1777-1778.  

At the beginning of the trail, a large earthen mound is to your left.  This is the impoundment for the Walnut Hill Desilting Basin, an additional trail is available on top of the berm. In other sections of the trail, multiple wetlands areas are present on your left. In the winter, expect to find ducks and geese.  In Spring look for frogs and salamanders.  

As you approach the downriver end of the trail, catfish island will be on your right.  Look for heron and geese breeding in the spring. The trail ends at Betzwood Access. Parking, boat launch, and restrooms are available here.  On your return trip, you may wish to turn onto the Commissary Trail and add a small bypass.

There are wonderful trails throughout the forest here. This includes bathroom facilities in the middle of the trails.

I started this hike in the main parking lot. I usually start over by the fish pond that I didn't go by with this hike. There are clearly defined trails to follow, and multiple paths to take to enjoy a few hours in the woods. There is a stream the flows through the middle of the forest the at the trails cross over multiple times.

Although the southern terminus of the trail is designated as being at Rt 356 in Freeport, hikers are warned NOT to attempt to follow the trail across the railroad bridge over the Kiskiminetas River. Unfortunately there's not any particularly viable alternative route for foot traffic. When beginning from the south, consider treating the parking area at Godfrey Rd as the southern terminus.

There are nine open/AT-hut-style shelters accessible via spurs off the trail. Unfortunately, there aren't consistent signs/blazes pointing to the shelters, and some are a considerable distance from the blazed trail. (Please contribute/update if you have details on shelter locations and conditions.)

As with other trails in the area, the Baker Trail runs across some private land in addition to public and utility land. The trail occasionally has to be rerouted to accommodate changes in land ownership, etc. When in doubt, always follow the blazes.

This trail is mostly doubletrack, although there is a section that cuts across Mill Road that is paved. This is a well-marked, multi-use trail that is used all year round. 

The great thing about this trail is the relatively few street crossings given its length. There are only about 6 crossings. It is a shaded trail with a ton of trees. Keep in mind that this trail is multi-use so keep an eye out for bikers and even horses.

Between the creek and the horse farms, this rolling trail offers all you could want in a hike -- the sites, the smells and even some solitude.

This does hook up with the Lebanon Valley Rail Trail which can make your hike even longer if you so desire.

The trail starts at the high-point of the Blue Dot Trail on the Kittatinny Ridge and travels northeast along the edge of the ridge with views (between the trees) into the valley and farmland below. The best view on this trail is right at the start, at the junction with the Blue Dot Trail—hike south down the ridge about 50 feet to a rock outcropping. 

From the start, the trail heads northeast, paralleling the Appalachian Trail. As a reasonably level old road through the woods, it is a well defined path, but can be narrow at times.

About halfway along the trail, you'll see an open field which is the site of a Heliport used by the fire service. After about 3.0 miles, the road intersects with the Turquoise Trail which cuts through a valley and past Sunfish Pond to connect with the AT. Currently the trail is crossed with down logs at the intersection with the Turquoise Trail (though they may not remain), so be on the lookout for the Turquoise Trail intersection. The Mt. Tammany Fire Road continues to the Yards Creek Reservoir which is private property. If you continue past the Turquoise Trail, you'll have to turn around at the boundary and retrace your steps.  

Note: Where the trail starts at the top of the ridge, the Blue Dot Trail turns south to the Mt. Tammany Overlook, a short distance away, with great views of the Delaware Water Gap.
Parking at the end of Old Bethlehem Road. The turn in on 563 is not very well marked.

From the parking lot the trail starts as an extremely wide grassy track that heads directly to Lake Nockamixon. Once you reach the lake the trail narrows to single width and takes you through a primarily evergreen forest. This area features views of the lake, and a surprising number of fallen trees. The trail then slopes upward and becomes rocky taking you through a deciduous forest. Once you reach the bridge over a small stream bear left and continue up the hill following the stream. The path to the right is unmarked and leads to the High Bridge Trail. This final section of the trail runs parallel to the High Bridge Trail and leads back to the parking lot.

To get to the trail, you can park in the Equestrian Trailhead parking at 1838 PA Route 168.  Then follow the Appaloosa Spur Trail.  For a nice 10k follow Nichol Road to create a nice lollipop route.  What's really nice is you can add to that route very easily by combining the multitude of other "better" trails in the area.

From the Historic Rittenhouse Town Parking Lot, head southwest on the paved path. The path will take you along the beautiful Wissakickon Creek and down to Main St. at the far edge of Manayunk. 

The path is well-maintained and has bikers, walkers, joggers, and people fishing. Turn around and hike back if want a fun, easy 3 mile hike or turn left, cross over Forbidden Drive and head up the dirt trail on the other side of the road to make this a nice, semi-difficult 5k.

This trail offers quick access from the Perkiomen Trail trail in Graterford to take you through Skippack Township over to Evansburg Park. There are a few offshoots that take you through Palmer Park to the shops in Skippack.

North Trail Lower Loop is a short trail that travels along a nose on the east side of Camelback Mountain. It's mostly flat through mixed hardwood forest. The further point out passes between some rocky cliffs.

At the northern terminus, this trail intersects the North Trail, which connects back to the South Trail and parking lots.
Land Manager:  City of Philadelphia - Parks & Recreation

Trail is in state game lands so be sure to wear orange, especially late fall and winter. No facilities at the parking lot but the interstate exit is less than two miles away with gas station and several fast food places.

This is a short hike with a rewarding view. The eastern leg is the steeper and more rocky section. Up near the overlook there is a millstone that was abandoned many years ago when this area was mined and quarried, which makes for an interesting stopping point.

trail_name: John P. Saylor Trail (Middle Ridge Loop)
description: Swinging bridge is no longer closed. Cross with care or wade through the shallow Clear Shade Creek. The trail is EXTREMELY muddy in some spots.
Mid State Trail (MST)

This trail is about as wide as an ATV track. There is a significant climb in first or last mile of trail (depending on the direction you hike). The terrain is dirt and loose rocks, but not overly technical.

The trail begins along House Rock Road at an entrance to House Rock Nature Preserve. The trail meanders slowly downhill, crossing House Rock Run before it connects with the Conestoga Trail. From here, it travels SE along the river for over a mile. Several beautiful views of the river below are offered along the way. Along this leg will be a stream crossing, Brubaker Run. 

Eventually, at about the 1.5-mile mark, the Ralph Goodno Trail will separate from the Conestoga Trail by turning left and making its way uphill. The trail will take you through more forest and along Reed Run. You'll travel along a couple farm fields before crossing a large open meadow and finally arriving at House Rock Road. Turning left and walking along the road will take you back to the parking lot where you began.

The Shingle Mill Trail begins near the Environmental Learning Center at Black Moshannon State Park on the north end of the Lake Loop Trail. Heading north from the lake, the trail follows the creek, traversing lowland terrain until it connects with the Allegheny Front Trail at the base of a hill.

Accessed from Tranquil Trail in the valley, or off of South Clayton Trail.  Entering from the valley, this trail starts with a quick switchback before leading to gentle rolling, yet a steady climb to South Clayton.  

Hikers can use this trail to access southern sections of the park, which offer more singletrack.

Bradema Trail is a beautiful, serene and solitary hiking/MTB/trail-running singletrack trail. Some small tree roots, rocks, and a horseshoe curve make this trail a fun frolic through the woods. Although you are not far from the major trails in Frick Park, you won't see them (until you cross the Biddle Trail)-- and it's just you and the woods.
This is the easier singletrack part of the trail around the reservoir.  Mostly buff singletrack, a few roots and logs.  Watch out for wet spots in the fields.
Nice bathrooms, boat rentals, beach, good parking. No food or water available to buy, bring your own.

The Ridge Trail connects the east and west side of Clear Creek State Forest. Along the way, you'll pass cascades and hike through hemlock and spruce forests, as well as thick rhododendrons. For the most part the terrain is gentle until the intersection with the Window Trail. From here to the river, the trail is very steep until it hits the River Trail.

Nice parking lot for plenty of parking. As you start out there is a small planked walkway across some swampy grass. Trail overall is in good shape, well blazed and easy to follow. The closer you get to the waterfall, the climbing is foot AND hand, meaning you'll need legs and hands to safely get closer to the waterfall as they're large boulders. I visited in November 2020 so there was very little water. In spring, it'll be a different story as is the case in Winter as it'll start freezing up over time. Consider what the weather has been prior to visiting.

Enter the trail from Brown Road at the start of a section of guard rail. The trail follows a stream making several crossings. In spring, this section of trail is full of wildflowers.

The trail then makes a sharp turn, covering over 100 feet of gain in less than a quarter mile. At the top of the climb you'll come to a grassy patch of forest with a fork in the trail. The trail to the right is the North Trails section. Stay left to stay on the Spur Trail. From here, the trail dives, losing all the elevation gained in the same amount of distance.

You'll end at a Blue Door and the Braille Trail.

Figure 8 Trail is Trail 500 on legacy maps. 

Primary access is via the dirt fire road road on the south side of Knowlton Rd, and the road narrows to doubletrack. Look for the trail to branch off to the right to follow the route - you'll end up back on the doubletrack at the end of the hike. 

There is an alternative connector signed for access to the Figure 8 Trail off Knowleton Rd, on MTB Project as  Figure 8 Trail - Knowleton Road Connector, which is a good exit, but not a great entrance to the trail due to steep grade uphill from Knowleton Rd to the Figure 8 Trail. 

You'll encounter a section where the trails cross at a 4-way intersection, thus the name, Figure 8. Just proceed straight through the intersection, and you'll eventually loop around and come back through. This applies no matter whether you're going clockwise or counterclockwise.

There is a lot of dried pine needle cover on the ground and hilly terrain, these trails drain well and can be used shortly after rainfall without much mud.

A reasonable downhill that is easy to climb too. Watch for lurking rocks and holes. This is a doubletrack that is open to horses and snowmobiles in the winter. DCNR does keep the grass cut to some degree

Find this trail off of the Underwood Rd/ Smays Run Rd/North Run Rd intersection or Beaver Rd.

This trail begins at the parking area and follows Roaring Run for most of its length. 

Not far from the trailhead, there is an incredibly steep section. If the water is low enough or there is a rock bridge, it's sometimes possible to cross the stream quite easily.

About a mile in, the rocks become more sparse and the trail becomes less technical. At about 2 miles from the parking lot, the trail meets up with Sand Spring Trail and the Sand Spring campsite.

Ernst Trail follows the Meadville-Linesviile Railroad built in 1880. The rail line used to transport visitors and good from the main Pennsylvania line. With the decline of rail travel, the railroad eventually passed into history, but this great trail remains. 

Visitors to the trail will enjoy the gentle grades, and the lush, shaded terrain. The trail is located at the bottom of one of the most diverse creeks in Pennsylvania, a fact that can be seen even from this popular route. Along the way, visitors will pass through dense hemlock thickets, and make their way under various types of hardwoods. Eventually the heavily wooded portions will open up into scenic meadows, which are the perfect place to stop for a picnic or a snack.

This is a wide and easy trail. One end starts at a connection to the Beltz Trail and passes the Pumphouse Trail. The other end connects to the Waterline Trail that leads to the Pumphouse Trail Parking area. The trail features a variety of tree species and is beautiful in the fall.

South Drive Trail is a wide doubletrack gravel road that allows hikers to move quickly in an east/west direction on the south side of the Brady's Run Park.

This is a nice rail trail running along Indian Creek. To find the trailhead at Jones Mills you have to come in on a side road. There are many other access points including parking areas in Champion and Indian Head.  

Note that there is another section of rail trail heading north from Jones Mills (parking off 381) but at this time there is no signed connection linking the two trails.
Great hike through the city of Philadelphia. Wonderful views of downtown, Boathouse Row, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and much more.

This trail is the main trail that runs through the Forest Cathedral Natural Area in Cook Forest State Park. It is blazed with a blue and yellow rectangle. The trail begins branching off of the Toms Run Trail and climbs steadily as it enters into the old-growth. As it continues the passive management of the forest almost makes it feel as though you are entering into the forest moon of Endor.  

As it climbs it passes junctions with various other trails through this area. Once the trail levels off these are some wonderful opportunities to view the treetops of the enormous trees. The trail then turns to the left and drops steeply. Here, there are exceptional views as the grade of the trail allows you to see full trees right in front of you. 

Eventually, the trail flattens out and turns to the right. The rest of the trail is a slight and scenic descent. On the right, as the trail nears its terminus, there are both a memorial fountain and a plaque designating this area a National Natural Landmark. The trail then ends in the parking lot for the Log Cabin Inn Environmental Education Center.

This trail begins at the bridge to the playground from the Greenbelt and runs along the backside of the ball field. The first half of the trail is relatively easy going with some mostly flat terrain. The latter half of the trail picks up with some climbing, more rolling terrain and larger obstacles. 

This is a popular trail with cyclists, so keep an eye out!

A small yet lovely section of forest adjoining the Central Elementary property.  

Low grades and a flowing trail with small obstacles (mostly roots) make this a simple hike through a uniquely fern-filled and green section of forest, especially in the summer.

This trail is easily accessed from the Middle Road parking area. Proceed east across the open gravel lot and follow the gravel road approximately 100 meters until the trail appears on your left, entering the woods just above the small stream crossing (one step and you're over it).
No restroom access.

Starting from State Route 407, this trail leads you either to Kennedy Creek Trail and Lee Hill or out to State Route 524 across from Bear Paw Trail and Turkey Hill. It's a pretty mild trail with some roots in sections. 

We call Ranger our bellwether trail because it gives a pretty indication of how the rest of the system is holding up. If Ranger is sloppy then turn around and head home because the rest of the trails are likely just as bad. If most of Ranger is in good shape then you're probably good to go!

The new Maguire Trail is a reroute of the old trail. The steep climbs have been eliminated and the number of switchbacks have been reduced significantly. The trail still loops through the woods but it's now la little more sustainable, unlike the old route. This new route is a much more enjoyable hike than the previous one.
Rocky at the end while you look out from "Saint Anthony's nose" and can see up the river to Martin's Creek. Beautiful overlook.

Horse Trough splits off of Bench Trail just after the entrance. It generally parallels Bench Trail but instead of descending, stays more level and then climbs a bit before crossing Riverview Extension Trail. This section starts out tight and twisty along a ridge that used to form a small pond. At the midpoint of the trail, there is an old concrete Horse Trough on the downhill side of the trail. From here, the trail gets less winding and eventually ends in a clear cut area before joining Lower Riverview Trail. You can continue  down Lower Riverview Trail trail to access Concrete Block and Homeless Camp.

The Kitchen Sink Loop is the big boy for this trail system. Over 3 miles of up and down, this trail rolls nicely through an old junkyard, house foundation, and Nikks Big Banana.  When people hike this, they might get to the bottom and say, "Man I cant wait to do this entire trail again!"

Kitchen Sink starts off of Up & Out Loop. Hang a right and head up the side of the mountain. It looks horrible, but once you get to the top the trail is rolling all the way to the 3D climb.  Climb that and youll be on your way to some really easy well-maintained trails. Be sure to enjoy the wildlife while youre up there. You'll encounter deer and squirrels, so make sure youre paying attention. Continue onwards and youll end up at the Old Access Road. From there, climb to the top of the Access Road, and make sure you play around on the old House Foundation.  

After the foundation, youll hit some really easy trail until you get to the old junkyard. Watch your step; youre in an old junkyard. From here you'll have two more small, but lung busting climbs before you hit the final descent.  Slog up those two and youre almost home-free. Once you're at the bottom, you'll meet up with the Up & Out Loop. Hike that back to the parking area!

Take the Red Loop from the parking lot, past the information kiosk, down a hill and into the forest to reach the Purple Loop. This short trail goes over a small wooden bridge and around a short loop. From this trail, it is easy to see a geologic outcrop that is specific to the area.

The hike begins with a relatively easygoing section of trail across the ridge to the top of the "The Fall Into Hades" descent. Hikers can turn left and plunge into the depths, or decide to live life on the "straight and narrow" by heading straight onto Yinz G.O.Y.S. as a bypass of this switchbacking downhill.

From Camp Conly Access Road, you'll encounter a very steep downhill almost right away. Weave your way in between rocks and trees. It gets steeper as you get down the trail, and then right towards the end, it gets fairly rocky, so be careful and watch your footing. The trail end at the Little Bear Creek Access Road.
This segment spans a loop south between two crossings of Haul Rd / T820 from Five Points: Trail 300 and Five Points: Trail 320, 330.
Stay off of the railroad tracks.
Be aware of mountain bikers descending this trail.
The railroad tracks are private property and very dangerous.

This trail is signed as Expert at either end. It's typically done as a descent (by mountain bikers) from Wolf Rocks Trail to Fish Run Trail along an unnamed stream, but can be traveled in the uphill direction also. Sections are steep and rocky.  Users can then regain their 200 feet of elevation by hiking up the less steep Fish Run Trail or continue on downhill on Fish Run to take Linn Run Road back up the hill.

From roughly 2.5 miles up Skyline Drive Access Road, look for the flowers hanging on the right. The trail is on the opposite side and can be tough to see unless you are looking hard for it.

When going in the downhill direction (as mapped), you start up the trail to crest the hill, then make your way down through rocky sections with some exposure to the north side. It is steeply downhill, hitting 15% grade or more. After the exposure, you'll get back into the woods where you'll come to a section that has "No Biking" signs posted. Continuing down the hill will get you near the quarry operations on Sulpher Springs Road.

If you are coming from Noels Trail, prepare for a tough, tough climb.
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary

This connects from the northern section of Haul Rd to near the entrance to the Model Airplane Airport at Kramer Rd.
It is a fairly level trail.
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary
At times, you are on the edge of a steep hillside.
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation

Starting at parking lot .5 miles past Old Rittenhouse Town head north up the wide, fairly well maintained path. This 5.5 mile trail follows Wissahickon Creek and ends at the intersection of Andorra Road and North Northwestern Road. 

Along the way you'll pass lush fauna, lots of chances to explore trails that spring off of Forbidden Drive, as well as other cool attractions: 

At approximately mile 2, look across the creek at the very cool Fingerspan Bridge.At approximately mile 2.75, you can get lunch or a snack at the Valley Green Inn.At approximately mile 3.5, look across the creek and see the statue of the last Lenni-Lenapi Chief.At approximately mile 4.5 is the Red Covered bridge. 

There are a ton of options getting back if you want a change of scenery; both the Yellow Trail and Orange Trail connect back, though they are quite a bit longer and not nearly as easy.

This really is a beautiful area in the city of Philadelphia.

This is an enjoyable singletrack trail through the forest. It is marked with Red blazes but they are few and far between and the big turns on the trail are not marked with the typical double blaze indicating a direction change. The trail is relatively easy to follow except  around the 3 to 3.5 mile mark at the highest point of the trail where the trail loops back and forth. 

There are several unmarked off-shoot trails in this area that, if followed, will lead you astray. The Hiking Project mobile app helped correct our missteps. The trail runs almost entirely on the ridge top with the major elevation changes on both ends of the trail.

The Pennypack Trail begins in Huntingdon Valley in Montgomery County and continues south through wooded Lorimer Park and on into Philadelphia County. A portion follows the former Fox Chase-Newton Branch line. 

A highlight of the pathway is its passage through Pennypack Park, one of Philadelphia’s most beloved parks, which offers several miles of unpaved trails for mountain bikers and equestrians. From the park, the rail-trail offers a paved route all the way to the waterfront of the Delaware River. Along the way, you’ll follow Pennypack Creek through rolling hills and curves.

In 2015, the trail was extended to the communities of Bryn Athyn, Rockledge, Lower Moreland, and Upper Moreland. It continues along Pennypack Creek (including a 143-foot bridge over the scenic waterway) and now totals just over 14 miles.

The McDade Recreational Trail provides visitors with a cornucopia of ecosystems, landscapes, and trail experiences to enjoy, all the while it is exceptionally easy to travel thanks to its crushed gravel surface. 

With over 14 parking areas variably spaced along the route, the McDade Recreational Trail provides all users with an appropriate length of trail. Parking areas can be as close as half a mile, and as far as five miles apart.

For those wishing to travel along the trail one-way, the National Park Service funds a free weekend bus service that stops at many major trailheads along the route. To view the schedule, click here.

Be aware that there are no services along the route, so be sure to bring all the food and water you'll need along with you. 

While the terrain is variable along the trail, each section exhibits a distinct nature: some are flat ribbons of gravel along the river, while others climb up the valley walls, and some are in between. 

Regardless of the section traveled, visitors to the McDade Recreational Trail are bound to have a wonderful and enriching experience along the banks of the Delaware.

Trail Segments are described below: 

From Hialeah Trailhead to Owens Trailhead, the trail traverses gently graded pastoral farmlands, complete with paint-peeling fences and rustic out-buildings.From Owens Trailhead to the park headquarters, the trail leaves the river's flood plane and climbs steeply up the valley walls through densely forested switchback turns.From the park headquarters to Bushkill Access, visitors will wander along rolling terrain, while keeping eyes peeled for the crumbling foundations of buildings constructed in a bygone era.From Bushkill Access to Milford Beach, the trail skirts the Delaware on a thin slice of land before leveling out near Schneider Farm, where it continues along gentle grades to Milford Beach.

One of the most notable trails in western Pennsylvania due to its length and combination of challenging ascents, fun descents and "deep in the forest" feel. The trail actually parallels Skyline road along the ridge top, so the remote feeling is a bit of an illusion.  There is also a not-to-be-missed view point just before the final descent to the Lick Hollow Picnic area.

There are multiple options for how to set it up as a loop hike. One option is Quebec Odyssey which uses road hiking for the return.  

Whitetail starts at the North parking area of the Quebec Run area, which also has trailheads for Hess Trail and Miller Trail. The first real stream crossing is at Long Run, where the Long Run trail goes off to the right. Instead cross the stream continuing with a long climb up the other side. As it tops out, there will be a short descent then a pipeline cut crossing. After awhile, the trail crosses Skyline road where you'll pass a parking area that could be used for shuttles. After the road crossing, the trail is exceptionally fun as it twists and turns through trees, roots and rocks. The next notable feature is the descent to Redstone creek, where you end up on an old logging road. At this point look for the singletrack down to the creek crossing (don't hike down the road). 

After crossing the creek, there will be some climbing before you arrive at a doubletrack which you need to descend on for awhile. Continue on with the descent following the blazes alongside and looking for the point where the singletrack continues off to the right. Shortly thereafter you'll arrive at the junction with Pine Knob Trail. Just before the final descent to the right on Pine Knob trail, take the left to check out the Pine Knob overlook. Then return to the descent to Lick Hollow Picnic area. This descent is challenging fun. The Lick Hollow Picnic area is nicely situated with ample parking and toilets.
Land Manager:  USFWS - John Heinz at Tinicum

The biggest difficulty was finding the trail. The easiest access point to this 4.7 mile section is from the southern terminus. There is parking on the north side of the road, just after turning past Snowy Mountain Rd, while staying on 233. Look for a sign on the north side of the road (about 200 after right turn) with directions to the AT and Raccoon Run Trail. The trees are marked with blue blazes. 

The trail begins with a slightly rocky start before crossing over to the east side of 233, where it remains for this entire section. After crossing 233, expect another crossing over the Rocky Mountain Creek. The bridge is in good condition and did not show any signs of aging. A quick left turn after the bridge, and you'll begin the main leg of the trail moving northward, following 233. 

The trail has some slight gains and losses of elevation with nothing more than 3-5% for the first few miles. This is a great warm up section if you plan on hiking the length of the trail and back. We did this trail on February 13 and conditions here were sometimes not ideal. Certain areas were a little flooded (no higher than the ankle) due to snowmelt. 

After crossing one logging road, a second road crossing is needed. The trail picks up on other corner of the bridge. The last mile of the trail was the most difficult. There can be icy conditions due to being on the shaded side of the mountain among lots of evergreen trees. Here, hikers will encounter the biggest changes in elevation.

trail_name: Tuscarora Trail Section 7: Cowan's Gap State Park to PA 16
description:
The Bird Run Shelter looks nearly new with a clean composting toilet -- clearly doesn't get much use. It is about 6 miles to Cowan's Gap State Park, where you can catch a shower, go for a swim, relax on the sandy beach, refill water bottles, and eat a meal at the concession. Immediately exiting the parking lot headed south, the trail crosses the road and climbs about 600 feet.  

It is roughly 5 miles to the The Big Mountain Shelter, which again appears relatively clean and rarely used. The fire pit is surrounded by large stones skillfully arranged like furniture and a spring fills a small pond about 200 yards to the south. About 0.75 miles uphill is the Big Mountain overlook, which is a spectacular site to catch a sunrise or gaze at the stars. The hang gliding ramps at Route 30, about 3 to 4 miles further, provide a scenic view to the west.

Park at Jo Hays Vista to begin the trail. You'll follow a track that goes along the top of a ridge with some beautiful scenic views of Rothrock State Forest. The trail connects on each end to the Mid State Trail (MST - Section 8).

The best access for this trail begins at Gilbert Road. Driving along Ridge Road from Shippensburg Road, you'll find parking for 6 vehicles near the power line. The map shows the intersecting road as Fegley Road but the trail signs on Ridge Road indicate it is Gilbert Road. Proceed under the power lines 1/4 mile to an open area. Look for a sign post for Astronomy Trail to the right of the grassy area. There are occasional red blazes. 

From here, the trail remains fairly level on hard packed soil, passing through open woodland with acres of blueberry bushes and mountain laurel. The trail becomes narrow in places from the overgrowth. At 1.5-miles, the trail begin a rocky descent to Milesburn Road within sight of Baltimore Rd. There is a private driveway across the street and possibly space for 2 cars in a pull off spot on Milesburn Rd.
Parts of the trail are overgrown and hard to make out. Stick to the blazes. Generally a casual hike, but at times gets pretty steep.

You can start the Skyline Trail either on the eastern Golden Eagle Connector Trail or at the top of the Lookout Trail. If you're looking for a more difficult hike, you should start to the east on the Golden Eagle Connector Trail and work your way toward the North Lookout. At the end of this trail, you'll have to literally climb with your hands and feet up large boulders to reach the top.

This trail begins in Huntingdon Valley in Montgomery County and continues south through wooded Lorimer Park where it ends shortly after crossing Shady Lane. It's possible to divert from the trail in Lorimer park or travel along Shady Lane and Pine Road to reach the Pennypack Trail - Philadelphia County section.

In 2015, the trail was extended to the communities of Bryn Athyn, Rockledge, Lower Moreland, and Upper Moreland.
Please be advised that you have to PAY to use this trail, or be risk being arrested for trespassing.
Parking is available across from the campground office, at the beach and at the public boat launch. Restrooms are at the beach and the boat launch. A seasonal snack bar is at the beach.

Part of the Montour Woods Conservation Area, this is a very nice trail with parking on both ends. The trail can become muddy at times, but the elevation is pretty flat with only about 90 feet in elevation change. 

There is a nice pavilion at the east end of the trail for picnics. Shortly after the start of the trail, you'll see a small waterfall on Meeks Run. There are two small creek crossings along the trail where you'll need to hop across rocks. Having waterproof shoes and a walking stick can be helpful. 

If you start at Hassam Road, you'll take a Connector Trail, which will end up taking you through a wetland on top of a boardwalk.

This trail is blazed blue, but not well, though it's not hard to follow the trail without the blazes. 

You can pick up other trails in the conservation area such as the Powerline Trail, Oil Well Trail, Cave Trail, and the Honeydew Trail.

Beautiful and simple loop on old railroad beds and gravel roads through the woods and marsh. 10% gravel road, 80% doubletrack, 10% singletrack.
The trail is soggy in spring and slightly overgrown, so prepare for floribunda roses to grab at you.

This section of D&L Trail connects Allentown and Bethlehem, the two largest cities along the D&L Trail, but users would never know it. Trips on the canal towpath are tranquil with the Lehigh Canal on one side and the Lehigh River on the other side. The trail follows the towpath and provides a relatively smooth, mostly gravel biking and hiking surface. 

Ample parking is available at both the Allentown Lehigh Canal Park and Bethlehem Sand Island Trailheads. The Allentown Lehigh Canal Park Trailhead is also a Lehigh River Water Trail access point and the Bethlehem Sand Island Trailhead is near a water trail access point. Please refer to Wildlands Conservancy's Lehigh River Water Trail website for more information on trips along the water trail.

trail_name: Horse-Shoe Trail: French Creek State Park Segment
description:

In order to get here, you have to hike Musser Gap Trail first and then continue through Frog Hollow Trail. The trail is fairly easy (I did it hiking with my dog). Some stones on your way might provide a challenge, but they're easy to avoid. Deer can be seen here. The trail is easy to follow as it is marked with pink little flags inserted on the ground, red paintings on the trees, and blue plastic ribbons.

Mid State Trail (MST)

Follow signs from the Scenic Loop (paved) for the Rocky Run Trail. Exit through Gate 1, making sure to close the gate behind you. Follow blue trail blazes, making sure to pay attention to double blazes, which indicate a turn in the trail.  This trail will take you alongside Rocky Run Creek, crossing it twice. Take note of the weather, as the creek will swell in size after storms.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park
Mid State Trail (MST)

To access this trailhead, you'll drive back Little Bear Creek Access Road from Route 87 approximately 1.5 miles. There is space to park along the shoulder of theroad. A trailhead marker is at the driveway into a large hunting camp. You'll walk up the driveway, past the large camp on your left and see where the trail heads into the woods towards Painter Creek.
Mid State Trail (MST)

Yield to hikers, always.

This trail is a great scenic doubletrack and starts off the east end of Fisherman Cove Trail, then connects to the Ho-Ya-Neh Trail, before it turns into a doubletrack right before it meets the Ridge Trail. The Pipeline Trail, the Blunder Trail, the Dennison Run Trail, and the Kennerdell Trail are all farther along the river heading southward.
Mid State Trail (MST)
There's a large parking area across from the trail entrance.
Land Manager:  DCNR - Hickory Run State Park

Mid State Trail (MST)

This is one trail that's sure to make you sweat. The beginning of the trail is inclined but the path is clear and safe. As you get further up, the path becomes steeper and unreliable (rocks that move underneath your feet). Look to your left as you go uphill – deer often hang out here.

This trail starts out at Trough Creek State Park follows Laurel Run for a while before heading up the mountain to come back down and make a loop
The Bog Trail follows a boardwalk out over the wetlands of Black Moshannon Lake, with multiple viewpoints and informational signs.

From Lykens Rd head west until you see the second post for Doc Smith Trail; turn right When you come to the split in the trail and stay left to be on Rattling Creek Trail.  Stay left until you come back to Lykens Rd. The trail has bridges that cross several creeks.

This road links multiple trails together (Shittaka, Deer Tick, Chicken Peter, Peep Trail, Bear Gap Trail, Dutch Alvin & Chestnut Spring) and houses several of the parking areas for these trails as well as access to Kettle Rd, Flat Rd, Conklin Rd Alan Seeger Rd and Stone Creek Rd.

The Dragon's Back is a tough climb. It starts at the bottom of the Serpent's Tail downhill and climbs abruptly. The first climb is shorter and not as steep so you can speed your way up it, but save some gas for the second steeper climb. After that, just settle in for a steady climb past the Dragon's Back to your right.

The Chuck Keiper Trail is a 50 mile backpacking trail in the remote Pennsylvania Wilds.  The trail can be done as one larger 50 mile loop or use the East Branch trail to create a 31 mile or 24 mile option. Starting from the main parking area on Rt. 144, across from swamp branch rd., hike the trail in a counterclockwise direction.  

The first couple of miles start off pretty mellow before dropping down into the first big decent into the Fish Dam Wild Area.  Hike to the stream and then climb out via a short, steep climb.  Next you'll drop down into the Burns Run Wild Area.  This is a long decent to the stream with a long and steep ascent out of the wild area.  Next, the trail leads to the Yost Run area.  It is a long, gradual ascent out of Yost Run.  You'll be rewarded with a series of waterfalls toward the end of Yost Run.  Cross Rt. 144 at an alternate trailhead parking area and then begin a decent into the Eddy Lick area.  You'll meander along Eddy Lick and come across several remnants of the old logging era.  

After Eddy Lick enjoy a long stretch of  moderate terrain that mostly follows old logging roads.  At approximately mile 28 the Chuck Keiper intersects the East Branch Trail.  You can take this trail to cut the larger loop in half.  Continue hiking the rolling terrain to the Cranberry Swamp area.  Take the loop around Cranberry Swamp or bypass if you want to cut some mileage.  Next head into a smaller drainage with a moderate climb to Mill Run Rd.  After crossing Mill Run, drop into the steeper Boggs Run area. Hike along Boggs Run for sever miles before climbing out and coming to a vista once you cross Peters Run Rd.  

Next drop into another drainage and cross Rt. 144 again.  Descend into the final drainage of the hike and follow the stream for a while before climbing out to join Barneys Ridge Rd.  Take a short side trip to Big Rocks Vista.  After a little road hiking, veer to the right and back to the parking lot. Finish with the great vista from the parking lot.  PA DCNR provides a good trail map or there is a detail trail guide by Dave Gantz.

This trail can be accessed from the dam parking lot or from Buckskin Trail. From Buckskin Trail, the Camp Trail falls down the hillside to cross over a small creek with an immediate jump up the opposite hillside. Here, you'll find a pair of stone structures. The trail juts right and continues along the hillside all the way to the dam before crossing a park road and finishing up at the dam parking lot.

While hiking along the hillside, you'll have plenty of opportunity to look out over the valley floor and the creek that winds its way through. While only a 100 feet up, it's a great section that takes your mind away from hiking.

This crusher fine rail trail takes hikers from Newville to Shippensburg and vice-versa. If you're looking for a mellow out-and-back hike, look no further than the CVRT.

Though this trail is buffered by trees in some areas, you'll have expansive views of South Mountain and Blue Mountain for nearly this trail's entirety. The folds of the surrounding Appalachian topography are very apparent from this vantage.

In addition to these Appalachian mountains, you'll note that almost every property this trail rolls through is a farm. This valley is so filled with farms because of its flat topography, access to water, and its limestone-rich geology.

Soils formed from limestone-rich rock is subsequently rich in calcium carbonate. This soil component improves the nutrient uptake of plants by increasing the pH of the soil. This also affects water penetration of the soil and provides plants with calcium and magnesium.

Fully tree covered, several wet areas depending on the time of year; this trail is not heavily used so there may be a lot of leaf cover on trail although it has recently been upgraded and the dirt singletrack is now quite evident
There is hunting during the fall so use caution on the trails.

After crossing the yellow gate, it's an easy trail to follow. The trail is a double lane, and is very clear.

You park at the highest point of the trail. Then it is an easy descent until you reach a campsite. There is one turn on the left side of the trail that you can take to extend your hike, but otherwise this is just an easy 1.2-mile trail out to a campsite.

The campsite offers a fire pit and a good viewpoint through the trees.

This trail needs a bit of description!
Be prepared to meet horses on the trail and make sure pets are leashed at all times. Good bug repellant is strongly recommended.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Weiser State Forest

Homewood Trail connects the Bowling Greens to Tranquil Trail on two ends, one end near the Homewood Cemetary and the other end at the bottom of the valley in the center of Frick Park.

There are several small singletrack sections that branch off of this trail which can be tied together.  A good start is Homewood Trail to Hawthorne Trail Connector to the Hawthorne Trail to the Undercliff Road Connector to Undercliff Road to Undercliff Trail to Forbes Ave. Use caution with Forbes Ave Crossing and take Forbes ave to Biddle / Braddock Trail connector to access the tennis courts and more trails along the eastern ridge branching off the Braddock Trail.

This is a nice and easy trail through old-growth forest that parallels Toms Run. Throughout the trail, it crosses several bridges. However, the first bridge (at the time of writing) is closed because of structural issues and, thus, requires a mildly tricky crossing via stepping stones. It continues along the run and gives views of both old-growth trees and a landscape that has been very passively managed. The trail is well maintained, but is not, in fact, marked. The terminus of the trail is across a swing bridge that traverses the run. This is a nice and somewhat hidden feature that is fun for the whole family.

This is a short doubletrack that starts off relatively flat then increases in steepness as you climb up to Rte 504 (Rattlesnake Pike). Is a great way to get to Tram Rd. from Smays Run Trail instead of using the forest roads.

Access this one from Smays Run Trail, off Benner Rd. or Underwood Rd. for the lower section, and off of Rte 504 (Rattlesnake Pike) for the upper portion.

Jaws is one of the more difficult trails on Spring Mountain. It begins by going down the backside of the mountain on part of the Backside DH trail. 

It then veers off right down a series of very steep, rocky shoots separated by technical rock gardens to a section of singletrack before intersecting the Perkiomen Trail. Take the Perkiomen Trail back to the lower parking lot of Spring Mountain.

This trail is a multi-use trail. Didn't see too many people walking the trail when I went. The trail is a loop that can be travelled in either direction. One direction will give you smooth uphills and trickier downhills while the other direction gives you trickier climbs and smooth downhills. 

The technical climbs are somewhat steep with large roots making the footing difficult. There are also wooden bridges to cross along the trail. 

The trail has two areas that lead you to the main road for a brief period and then puts you back onto the actual trail again. The trail is marked with blue paint or wooden signs with a blue mark.  

There are a few logs as well, but these have a little dirt ramp to make getting over a little easier. About a quarter-mile of the trail is on the park side, which is open area with gravel for the trail. There are pavilions and bathrooms as well.

This trail begins at the boardwalk at the south end of Parker Lake. As it follows the boardwalk it zigzags over a shallow marsh. While it is bowed and in need of small repairs, it is a nice place to hike. Here is an opportunity to view the various wildlife alive in the lake including salamanders and small fish.  

After leaving the boardwalk, the trail transitions into a nice dirt path along the lake. When I did this trail, as we made this transition a bald eagle leaped from the branches above us and soared over the lake.  As it continues, there is a pine grove where the path widens to include a small group of rock formations. As the trail curves at the north end of the lake, it passes rocks that have been laid out to spell "Parker Dam" on the ground.

The trail then continues over the berm of the mostly earthen, CCC-era dam. To the right, just in the lake is a structure that supports a bat box.  Next, the trail comes to the part of the dam over which Laurel Run flows. This part of the dam is fairly ingenious as instead of a traditional bridge, a large area of steppingstones has been placed to accommodate for the movement of both visitors and the stream. The trail crosses these stones and climbs up stairs on the other side of the dam.

After the dam, the trail ventures into a more wooded section of the park.  This is the first time where the yellow blazes that mark the trail are both visible and necessary. The rest of the trail continues fairly flat and near the river, though there are some places that are overgrown and muddy.  This is a generally pleasant second half of the trail. The terminus of the trail is the bridge that crosses over Laurel Run.

This trail isn't well marked, so you'll have to work a little bit to get to the start. Start at the top of Woodrow Road and turn east. After about 100 yards, there will will be an open section with a doubletrack to the right and a trail into the woods on the left. Head up the doubletrack a little ways and the start of the downhill will be (somewhere) on your right. Make sure to use the Hiking Project mobile app to help find the way.

The trail starts out with the hardest section first with a steep and rocky section where you'll want to watch your footing. After that, the trail doesn't flatten out, but it gets a bit easier until ending at the SWMA #8 Haul Road.

This trail is moderately difficult and without too much climbing, but it passes near many boulders that offer a challenge if you desire. You'll see evidence of the routes that cyclists have been using, but use caution as these can be slick on foot. It's a great trail, with your fun only limited by your risk aversion (common sense?).

    Opinion

This forms part of a 3.3-mile loop is the southern part of the bigger Rock Run Trails and is known also as the Rock Run South Loop. It is best navigated from the Allegheny Front Trail (North) intersection to Headwaters Trail as this provides the better downhill. Near the lower  and the junction with Rock Run Trail, you'll run into large rocks (boulder size) that will challenge your balance and trails skills.

This trail connects Sumney Road trailhead and camping area to the rest of the system and intersects with the Mill Run Trail at the northern end.  There is also a connector with a bridge over Quebec Run to cross back to the Mill Run Trail about half way. 

The trail features sustained climbing in the north to south direction. The loamy soil drains well in wet weather. Expect a few creek crossings from tributaries to Quebec Run.

NOTE: Not to be confused with the Bear Run Nature Trail some miles west.

The trail starts across Landrus Road from a small parking area, which is notable for a plaque dedicated to the former Village of Landrus. (A connecting path north of the road leads to MST - Section 18.) The first 50 feet or so of the trail is wide enough for a car, and this width continues on a small spur to the right (west), where there is a small clearing with a fire pit. 

After the spur, the trail is singletrack and sparsely marked with very faded red blazes.Terrain is generally fairly rocky. The trail runs uphill in the Bear Run valley, passing a couple of waterfalls. Just under 1 mile from the road, the trail actually crosses Bear Run twice, which might cut your hike short depending on how much rain the area has received recently. Eventually, the trail separates from Bear Run and continues through woods, and becomes less steep. The trail terminates on the top of Hickory Ridge, where the Long Run Railroad Trail meets Bloss Mountain Road.

This trail winds around the top and center of Hillman State Park (Bavington) between the Five Points Trails and Old Airport Trail.  You'll hear buzzing coming from the Model Airplane Airport nearby and wonder if it's someone running a chainsaw in the distance.

These are less maintained than some of the other trails here, and may be hard to traverse in the heavy growth months.  Wear some pants and gloves, because the Jaggers will get you.

The Pickering Creek Dam Trail has some historical significance, as back in the 1900's they would dam up the area in the winter in order to collect ice which would be shipped to Philadelphia. The trail is relatively flat, and obstacle free, with an old bridge in the middle to get across the creek. 

There is a second trail that runs along the top of the ridge, once you cross the bridge near Bird Ln. The upper trail runs parallel to a housing development, and the trail to get there is fairly steep. One section even has a rope to help you get up over a small ridge, which can be a big icy/slippery during the winter months. Expect to see dog-walkers, nature photographers, and trout fisherman along the trail.

A rugged trail through an area where construction debris was dumped many years ago, and also passes by the remains of a campsite where a homeless dude lived in the woods. One of the more technical trails in Frick Park, and similar in feel to Concrete Block. Can be used to form a loop when combined with Horse Trough and Concrete Block.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park

One way to start this trail is to park at the resort and hike past the lake and then onto Tahoe Drive where the trail becomes obvious on the side of Tahoe Drive. Another way is to come up the 24 hour race climb and turn right at the top onto the singletrack just before you reach Airport Road.

As shown, the trail parallels Airport Road and goes onto the "island" section, which has a few interesting boulders to navigate. 

From the start, the trail mostly follows the contour with short bits of ascending and descending. Eventually, you'll come out on a doubletrack. Cross it to stay on the singletrack. 

This is the "island" part, stay to your left at the first junction and the trail will wrap around bringing you back out to the doubletrack. Here, if you again cross the road, you can hike a very short singletrack extension that brings you back to the road again. Turn right and head out to the end of the old runway avoiding some large puddles. 

At the end, you gain access to the Big Fern Loop, which is a loop trail that goes out to Dumbauld Road and back. You'll likely hear target practice in this area.

Follow the paved path from the visitor center until you reach a split. Take either path around the scenic route. There are often rotating exhibits by artists throughout the area to enjoy (giant wooden insects and custom tree-houses when I last visited) as well as the flora and fauna.
Most popular trail in the park, and for good reason. Diverse, wooded, follows a beautiful creek, but occasionally crowded.

This trail is a sweet 1.3 mile downhill that is typically used to connect Barrville Rd and Rag Hollow Rd. It is a nice alternative to using the road back to Greenwood Furnace State Park

The grade is pretty steady but there are some random large rocks, logs and the occasional washout hidden in the ferns.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Rothrock State Forest

The Drain begins at far end of Wave Pool parking lot.  From the lot take the trail to the right towards the white and blue gas line marker.  Follow The Drain as it twists and turns all the way out to McConkey Rd.

The Pink Hill Trail crosses Painter Road, offers hilltop views, a stream, a quite meadow, and passes the Chestnut Nursery. Named for the moss phlox that blooms each April, Pink Hill is a serpentine barren: an ecosystem with an underlying bedrock with high levels of toxic nickel and an imbalance of magnesium and calcium.

This trail departs from the Scenic Loop. It is marked by a small sign that you must be looking for, but also by a pink bench (far easier to see). Follow the grass path through "Gate 7", making sure to close the gate behind yourself. After crossing Painter Road, this trail will give a glimpse into several ecosystems. Enjoy several water crossings, moderate climbs, and a nice tour of the natural world.

This trail begins and ends on Lykens Rd. Also on the west end of the trail, it intersects with Rattling Creek Trail. It winds its way through the dense forest of the region, and don't be surprised if you turn the corner and see deer, rabbits, or a variety of bird species.

Comment Type:
