    Opinion
Parking is located at the start of the Red Trail.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Locust Lake State Park
Hunting is allowed in the fall, so be careful on the trails at that time.

From the parking lot, head east, go across the main rd and you'll see a path leading into the woods. Go a little way and you'll come to a "T" where you can go right or left to make the loop. If you go right you'll go about half a mile and you'll need to make a left hand turn to stay on the E. Loop Trail. This provides a pleasant loop passing through peaceful woodlands, and is a great way to see new trail all the way to and from your car.

Soon after entering off the fire road, there are some hills and motorcycle/ATV paths around a strip mine. Once you are done playing around on the hills, head east toward the river to find a trail that heads southward along the outskirts of the strip mine. This trail is not very long and is probably one of the easiest and most smooth rolling singletrack trails here.

Beautiful, varied scenery can be found on the Blue Blaze Trail. The gentle, rolling terrain and mostly navigable trail make it easy to take in the beautiful setting surrounding the trail. 

The eastern portion ties into the Blue Blaze Red Dot in three locations and features a stream in the southern area. As you head north there is a overgrown small field bound by connector trails to the Blue Blaze Red Dot at either end before turning west and then south on the upper portion.

Watch for muddy sections after wet weather.

This trail stems from the Scenic Loop (paved) trail. Follow the signs to reach the Painter Trail. This trail will take you out through "Gate 4" and into a field of flowers. Red blazes will bring you into the woods, over Rocky Run Creek, and then you'll climb up then back down several hills.

Pay attention to the color of the blazes (follow red) and for double blazes, which indicate a turn on the trail. This trail shares sections with the Minshall Trail, Middle Farm Trail, and Rocky Run Trail.
There is no real place to park at the trailhead.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Gifford Pinchot State Park

Take this steep trail from the intersection with Lookout Loop to Sawmill Trail. The lower portion of Roller Coaster Trail is not shown on the State Park map, but actually connects to the intersection with Sawmill Trail and Three Springs Trail. 

This is a downhill-only trail. The top third and bottom 1/3rd are quite nice and rolling, but caution should be used in the middle third of the trail as it is steep and can be loose and rutted.

This trail could use some description. If you know it, please adopt it and give it the love it deserves!

This is a long slow grind up out of Alan Seeger Natural Area up to Ruff Gap Trail or Greenwood Tower Rd and Broad Moutain Rd. As noted, you can get to Ruff Gap Trail as well as Yoder Trail and Telephone Trail (upper).
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - Chester County Parks
Land Manager:  City of Pittsburgh, PA - Parks
There's an excellent outdoor exhibit about the Boxer's Trail. Learn more about it here:  myphillypark.org/boxers-tra…

    Opinion

This is a 0.5 miles doubletrack/dirt road connecting the Green Trail to the Trexler Border Trail. The hiking on the trail is not too difficult. We accidentally left the Trexler Border Trail and used this path to get back on track. Along the way, we passed by the Mill Creek parking lot, which is another access point for this route and other trails in the area.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park

Black Gap Trail is one of the "must do" trails in the area. It's broken roughly into thirds and is often referred to as West, Middle and East sections by locals. The Middle section is wet for much of the year and might be worth skipping, unless you really want a challenge. And by wet, I don't mean muddy. The entire trail follows a drainage for a couple of vernal pools in the middle section and if there has been any rain, the middle section is more of a creek than a trail. It's all stone though, so it's pretty much only yourself that you're hurting. 

The preferred direction is from west to east. The trail starts off climbing up from Engle Road through a hemlock grove and is pretty open. Soon though the trail becomes a tunnel though rhododendron and mountain laurel, making for a very cool hike. This continues for about a mile until it intersects with the Handicapped Access Trail (referred to by locals by its original name, Jamboree Trail.) If you want to skip the middle section, go right and take the doubletrack for over a mile. 
The eastern third was re-routed in 2011 and has some rocky bits before dropping into the creek bed to finish out the trail. Be careful crossing the bridges as they can be slick.

North Valley Trail is a nice trail that follows the contours along the edges of Mack's three valleys. It starts at Big Timber, intersects with Sharp Valley, Forge Hill Road, Lost Valley, Ridge Camp Road, General Strickler Road, and eventually dumps out at Hammer Creek Road. Sections are winding with short climbs out of the valleys.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR Erie Bluffs State Park

This is fun five mile downhill from the intersection with Kettle Rd, but a grind to go up. Old Lewistown Pike connects at the lower end to this road as well as the bottom of BR & S Trail, also the southern (low end) of Sassafras Trail and Spencer Trail. At the very top end, you can go right up Greenwood Tower Rd or left down Ruff Gap Trail.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest
Like most of the trails in Denton Hill State Park, this is blazed sparsely with blue blazes, but is well-tread enough to follow easily.

Land Manager:  USFWS - John Heinz at Tinicum

Old Narrows Trail primarily follows the original road bed before the modern 192 was built, but that doesn't mean its doubletrack. The majority of the trail is a rolling singletrack with short punchy climbs and a few rocky sections. There are numerous driveways that cross the trail, so be on the look out for red blazes and you'll know you are on the right trail. 

The trail can be done in either direction, although east to west seems to be the preferred route.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park

The Wave Pool Trail follows orange blazes on the southern tip of Boyce Park near the wave pool. The trail is narrow singletrack, and may be overgrown at times. While there is one descent followed by a climb, the grades are moderate, and most will be able to tackle these features with ease. The main entrance to the trail is to the left at the entry way at Old Frankstown Road and exits onto the sidewalk near the lower parking loop for the Wave Pool.  

A good way to connect this trail is to follow the White Blaze Blue Dot trail from the log cabin to the Orange Blaze White Dot trail and cross Old Frankstown Road to the main trail entrance. 

After you exit the Wave Pool Trail, then follow the road back towards Old Frankstown Road and look for a clearing on the left towards the skate park and there will be a small un-blazed connector trail, Wave Pool Trail Connector, which will take you down to the corner of Cooper Road and Old Frankstown Road.  Cross Old Frankstown and look for the trailhead to Orange Blaze Black Dot.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park
Land Manager:  Lancaster Conservancy

A north/south singletrack route from Centerview Drive - Gravel Road to Outer Trail - Gravel Road following the Blue Blaze/Yellow Dot markings. 

There is some trail to be had here when heading north to south. It's also a great way to climb north as an alternate to the Outer Trail - Gravel Road.

There are many small connectors between this and the White Blaze, Outer Trail - Gravel Road, and White Blaze Blue Dot trails. You'll also find a shortcut to the Blue Blaze Red Dot and Blue Blaze Black Dot loop.

It may appear confusing on the map as it runs parallel with, but it doesn't overlap, the White Blaze trail for a short period with a few small connecting paths between.

This trail follows the Yellow Blaze markings. You can access it via a small unblazed access trail at the top of the loop or by simply using the Yellow Blaze Blue Dot connector from the Model Airplane Field. 

This trail is relatively short, and doesn't have much in the way of elevation gain, but hikers will want to use caution, as the dense tree cover makes for rooty and challenging terrain.

The trail starts at Fourth Ward Park with a decent climb to the top, on a dirt gas well road. Once at the top, it turns to dirt doubletrack and then down to singletrack towards the bottom. The path finishes at the sub-station on Fulton Run Rd.
A nice, flat, 1-mile loop that leaves from and returns to the Ice Rink parking area.

Trail starts in a grassy area just off the north side of the bridge going over the Clarion River. There is no parking, but this is a good trail to walk to if you are staying in a nearby cabin or campsite. The trail initially follows the Clarion River, and there is actually a side path you can take to go down next to the water on some big rocks. If you come back this way, this is a good spot to dip your feet in to cool down! The trail gets steep pretty much right away and doesn't really relent until you've reached Baker Trail at the top. You'll be climbing lots of rocks, roots, and stairs.

This portion of the Rock-n-Ridge trail extends from the intersection with the Sawmill Trail, to a T intersection. At the bottom of this fun descent, a left turn takes you to the bottom of the Crist Ridge Trail, and a right turn connects to the Mowery Hollow. 

Rock-n-Ridge Trail #4 is mostly used downhill. It is debated whether this or Crist Ridge Trail is the best downhill cross country trail in the Blue Knob State Park. From the intersection with Sawmill, the trail starts as a fast doubletrack downhill. The first portion is a grassy slope. After a while, the trail makes a loose left turn then drops into a rocky section. There is then a short rocky climb. After that is a twisty, turny downhill.

A wide, grassy trail with tracks and scat reflecting use as a wildlife corridor. A good trail to spot such signs. I started the trail near Group Camp 8 at the Jones Scott Singo Cemetery. According to the sign there's a Revolutionary War soldier buried there. Most graves are just marked with a fieldstone at the head and foot. The Ridge Trail also connects to a number of other park trails.
Land Manager:  City of Pittsburgh, PA - Parks

This is a mostly singletrack loop below Snyder's Point. Easily accessible from Riverview Ave or as a connector between Deer Hollow Trail and Violet Lane Trail.

Deer Trail is nicknamed the spine or backbone of BMP. This trail makes the most of an old logging road to connect to most of the other trails in the park. During the winter, it doubles in length as the vegetation that overgrows in the summer is gone.

The trail has some moderate hills, passing equally through farmland and forested areas. At times, there is some mud on the North side of the trail, but usually isn't too bad. Trail shoes are recommended.

Somewhat paralleling Pierson Run Road and accessible from the road ,this trail passes through beautiful deciduous forest with rolling hills. It can also be accessed from the Carpenter Trail through numerous connectors.  This trail is thoroughly enjoyable for easy running with only one big drop followed by a short, but steep climb. From this point, you can connect connect to the Blue Blaze via the Log Cabin area, the short Yellow Blaze Trail, and Orange Blazed Trails.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Bald Eagle State Forest

The Frank Gantz Trail is rated moderately difficult for hiking, so trail running is quite challenging due to the rocky terrain. If the ground is wet, the rocks can be extremely slippery and running would not be wise. 

The trail connects with the Lakeside Trail around Tobyhanna, which is an easy five-mile loop, and therefore the two trails can be coupled together for an ~11-mile run departing and returning to Gouldsboro State Park. Requires a reasonably slow pace in parts given the uneven and rocky terrain, but it is great fun if you like the challenge. 

The trail feels quite remote but is well-marked.

This trail is a good option for a nice downhill hike as the grade is easy and there are virtually no rocks. This makes it a good option for beginners. Take the gentle up and over the ridge apex from Brush Ridge Rd and then enjoy the downhill past the Goose Club Trail intersection and continue down to the intersection with Main Ski Trail.
Salamander dishes up a tight and twisting singletrack that doubles back and forth through the trees.

This segment of Bill Alberts Trail extends from a signed entrance off of Laurel Summit Road and follows a bouldery route to its intersection with Towhee Trail. Requires a short steeper climb just before the intersection. You can connect the beginning to/from Summit by following Laurel Summit Road a short distance toward the warming hut to find a short connector on the opposite site of the road.

This trail has sections with bumps, switchbacks, and an assortment of bridged and hard-armored creek crossings. On either end, you'll find connectors back to the upper loops, which ultimately lead back to the Shelter #2 trailheads.

For the Down & Dirty Loop, you start off on an old railroad bed and head west towards town.  Don't go too quick or you'll miss the quick uphill that takes you on the outskirts of a corn field and a low turn.  You'll eventually end up back on the railroad bed before you descend on two drops in the Dirty part of Down & Dirty.  Take the rest of the trail and head back to the railroad bed.

Indian trail works well for climbing and descending.  The bottom starts off as a grassy doubletrack that follows a deer fence.  As you climb, it turns into an old school rocky bench cut. Stay left as the deer fence bear to the right.
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary
Watch out for motorbikes.

Firelane Trail is a well maintained fire road / trail that runs from Commercial St to the Lower Frick Parking Lots.  

It can be used to connect to Lower Riverview Trail via the Firelane Trail Extension, the Tranquil Trail adjacent to the lower frick parking lot, or the Nine Mile Run Trail which runs along Nine Mile Run.
Depending on what direction you hike the trail, you have some good climbs on the southern portion of the tail and nice views of Glendale Lake on the northern half.
This trail allows you to add a little mileage when going between the Mill Creek Trail and the Raccoon Trail. It is about 1.5 miles of infrequently-visited singletrack.
Doubletrack trail that is not flat, but works great for connecting some of the other singletrack trails in the area together.
The A.T. is being rerouted onto the North Trail. The former A.T. section will become a side trail, called the Bypass Trail.

Newly signed as "Short N Sweet" also known as SSX trail. Marked as Trail 510 on legacy maps.

This is a short loop starting and ending on Knowleton Rd across from the Figure 8 Trail.  It's good to loop in with other trails as part of a longer hike.  Some moderate climbs, but nothing too steep. 

Short N Sweet Trail follows Yellow Blazes. Colt Trail crosses this trail in several places and shares a short climbing segment as well following Red blazes. The shared segment is blazed with both red and yellow blazes.

Orange triangle blazes.

Take this trail from the intersection with Group Camp to the intersection with Three Springs Trail. It is misnamed on the latest map as "Rock-N-Ridge" but it is better known as Clickety-Clack. 

This is a trail that's fun to do in both directions without a lot of elevation gain or loss. It is rocky but not intimidating rocky. It is a benchcut singletrack that is scenic and considered one of the best trails at Blue Knob.
Rest room access is at the bottom in the state park
Start just below the entrance to Trail 10 on Trail 2. The upper section is pretty rocky. The bottom is smoother and less rocky.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Tiadaghton State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Rothrock State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest
Squirrel Trail is a rolling and turning singletrack through the north end of the park. There are a number of off-camber turns as it moves through the trees.

Off of the Orange Blaze White Dot  this trail leads to the top of the ski slopes and Commissioners Pavilion. From the top of the slopes follow the trail to the west - northwest and pass the chairlift and the Park Office. The trail ends at the picnic area near Old Frankstown Road. 

Continuing on through the parking lot and past the gate will take you on a series of unmarked trails taking up all the park space west of Centerline Drive.
New trail built correctly for biking and running. Fun in both directions. The best access into the Camp Mack riding area. Bypasses the harder trails and washed out roads.

Note: This part of the Yellow Trail is different from has already been published here, and still just a small portion of what is marked on the state map at the Yellow Trail. LOTS of ways to vary your hike in this part of the Park. 
No restrooms anywhere near this trailhead. All areas in this part of the park are open to mountain biking, and some are open to the horses from the rental farm on the west side of the park. Watch your step!

This trail leads to an old quarry, hence the name. The first part of the trail is a rocky singletrack around the top rim of the quarry on the way down. At the end, watch for other users as the singletrack merges onto the Step trail.
Switchback hard left onto the Kurtz Gap Trail at the bottom of Kurtz Gap.
There is a parking lot at the bottom of Radar (Trail 1).
A short trail leading from Hopewell Furnace into the trail network of French Creek State Park. It starts with a strong climb before flattening out up top.

Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - Chester County Parks
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary

You can access this from either R.B. Winter State Park on the fishing side (just follow the Mid-State/Brush Hollow Trails or by the Fallen Timber Trail along Pine Creek Road (no winter maintenance). Cell service is non-existent for the most part.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park
A 1/3 mile portion of this trail is on a 2-lane highway.

The South Trail is on a large expanse of rocks with many good views. It's mostly manageable without much scrambling required, but watch your footing as many of the rocks will move when you step on them. Follow the blue blazes painted on the rocks. It's a scenic, but more difficult, alternative to the Appalachian Trail which runs parallel.
There are several unimproved stream crossings that may be uncomfortable for some, waterproof footwear is recommended.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park

This simple portion of trail is the least difficult hiking or biking in the western section of the park. It meanders across fern-covered terrain and is the easiest climb back to the top of the hill after descending Turn Down for What (TD4W) or Country Club. It is an excellent choice for a nice easy loop to hike, as it is one of the most beautiful sections of park. Beautiful vistas include overlooks of the valley that runs along the southeast of the trail.

The trail's only difficulty lies at the top of the hill near the Country Club entrance.
Red diamond blazes.

The trail can be accessed from Fulton from two points. The beginning of the trail at both points starts with a nice descent down to White's Run before it meanders back up. The smooth path is less traveled than others in the White's Wood Area but you may encounter other hikers and the occasional biker.

Bigelow Trail is a winding woods trail with a few challenging but small rocky patches to thread your way through.
Peep tail is great in both directions, obviously more fun to go down then up but either way is fine.

This is the northernmost section of trail between Five Points: Trail 310 and Five Points: Trail 340. This is one of the longer segments of trail. 

To connect to Segment #4, proceed southwest on Kramer Rd across from the trailhead and look for the entrance to Five Points: Trail 340 on your right (south) for the trail entrance.

Alternatively, you can add some mileage by hiking the Haul Rd / Airport Connector by going left onto T820 after exiting the trail and looking for the trailhead immediately after the westward bend in the road.
This loop is an intermediate level trail, with one bridge, and a large collection of banked turns and few bumpy sections.

This is the section of trail between Five Points: Trail 320, 330 and the Five Points parking area near the entrance to Five Points: Trail 360. 

It starts just off of the southern side of Kramer Rd, a short ways from the intersection of Haul Rd and Kramer Rd.  It eventually loops back west and terminates at Haul Rd. 

At the Haul Rd intersection, you can make a left turn and look for another trailhead shortly on your left to access the next segment, the Five Points: Trail 360.

If you proceed straight across Haul Rd, you can access a Connector trail which will short cut you back on Five Points: Trail 320, 330

The top of Step begins as an easy singletrack descent. About halfway down, the trail corridor is filled with a succession of man-made steps to take you back down to the parking lot. Near the bottom of Step, there are many off-shoots that split off the trail. All lead to the parking area or nearby road, but try and stay on the trail as best you can.

Starting at Painter Rock Road (or the Nedrow Trail), this connects you to the McKenna Trail.
Land Manager:  Cumberland County

This two-mile forest road is a climb from Coopers Gap Rd up and over with a great vista point near the top on the Coopers Gap Rd side.

You also get access to the top end of Shittaka Trail and Peep Trail on the Coopers Gap Rd side and Sassafras Trail on the Rag Hollow Rd side.

There is a neat vernal pool that appears in the spring. This is a loop, the left side offers a short, steep incline to get to the top and then a downhill most of the way back to the starting point. The right side follows where Mill Stream flows into the lake; often there are ducks, heron and an occasional beaver to be seen from this side of the trail.
Land Manager:  Natural Lands - Mariton Wildlife Sanctuary
Hard right switchback onto Spike Buck Trail to return to Pine Flat Road.

This is the section of trail between Five Points: Trail 340 and Five Points: Trail 350 

It starts just off of the eastern side of Haul Rd just south of the trailhead of Five Points: Trail 340 as it continues south until it reaches T446. 

From the T446 intersection, you can proceed directly across the road to the final segment, Five Points: Trail 350 which will take you back to the Haul Rd parking area, and Connector Trail (370), which will take you toward the Old Airport Trails.

This is the section of trail between Five Points: Trail 360 and the Five Points parking area near the entrance to Five Points: Trail 300. The trail is pretty level with just a little bit of climbing and descending.
Going from Shittaka Trail up, this is a steady slow slog. Coming the other the other way of Beautiful Trail, this is much more fun.

This trail connects from the Five Points Trails near the southern Haul Rd trailhead and T446 to Old Airport Trail to Trail 380 and Trail 390. It's a good way to get between the Five Points Trails to the Old Airport Trail and trails that branch off Knowlton Rd. 

Often this is a better option than hiking the Model Airport Trails, which tend to get more overgrown and become difficult to traverse during seasons with heavy overgrowth.
Restrooms on site.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Presque Isle State Park

Spring is a bi-directional singletrack trail that connects from Friends to Fulton. There are some rocky areas and tree roots to add some obstacles and keep things interesting. At the trail's low-point there is a small bridge crossing.

If you're hiking from the east, you'll encounter a set of three steps after the sharp turn after the bridge crossing. From there, the trail climbs steadily to intersect Friends and Fleming where hikers can choose a singletrack or dirt road descent.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest

Can be muddy in spots due to natural springs.

A nice elevated trail with a parking lot on either side that allows for almost a 5 miles down and back trip. The trail is completely paved the entire way, there will be a couple times that you take a ramp down toward the water's edge and back up, but it's a very easy incline.
This is a trail that links both sides of the two previous trails. It is an easier grade to the top of the ridge giving great views of the top and the way up.

This gray-blazed trail is located towards the periphery of the Haverford Reserve trail network, only accessible via the Meadow Trail. It is relatively flat with multiple connections to adjacent trails and bordering on the disc golf course.

From the Mount Misery Trail just off the Yellow Springs Road (near the Knox Covered Bridge), begin the uphill trek. The trail gains most of its elevation in the first 1/3 of the route, but continues gradually uphill for its entire length. Enjoy the lush, forested path past rock formations and small clearings. Just over halfway, the steep Wolfinger Trail descends to the east. Continue northwest along the Mount Misery Trail to its terminus at the Horse-Shoe Trail.

While you're near the Covered Bridge, take a moment to appreciate this historical landmark.

The Kildoo Trail starts at the covered bridge and dam and runs south to Eckert Bridge. There aren't any spurs off the trail and it is blazed well-enough that you won't get lost.

This trail is tough to hike with the boulders and roots, but it has access to large boulders sitting within the rapids and creek, offering some vantage points not gotten from the Slippery Rock Gorge Trail.

This trail is accessible from the main parking lot at the base of the spillway (eastern trailhead) or off the Appaloosa Trail.  Starting from the spillway, this trail runs across the basin before heading up to the ridgeline via a stream.  Once on the ridge you'll inevitably descend and rise crossing several streams as you make you way west.  

This trail is singletrack with several road crossings which normally don't present much difficulty getting across.  The trail is muddy in the hollows and has roots and ruts most of the way.

This trail follows the Fish Commission doubletrack from the hatchery in Bellefonte to the one at Shiloh Rd along Spring Creek. Between Shiloh Rd and the Rock Rd parking area, it is a singletrack. Often, you'll encounter fisherman walking along the path/doubletrack to their favorite spots.

This is a great place to get kids into the outdoors. If there is enough snow in winter, you'll also encounter XC skiers and snowshoers.

Use the parking area off Rock Rd, the parking access off Shiloh Rd, or the parking access off Spring Creek Rd.

If you start from the south you'll notice the elevation because you'll be going up...north. This route is not a loop trail, so to hike the full trail and get back to your car, you'll have to return the way you came. If the full 7+ mile outing seems like a bit much for one day, you can bring two cars, and leave one at the southern trailhead where the trail starts, and another at the northern trailhead. 

The way is marked by yellow or golden color trail I.D. blazes. Some of the blazes have faded a little in the southern section of the trail, so keep an eye out. The northernmost part of this trail does offer a loop section from the north trailhead, and this portion has golden with white blazes, distinguishing it is a loop trail.

There are park forest roads and other unmarked trails in the area, but if you focus on following the blazes, you'll stay on track.

The best way to enter the trail is from the Guyasuta Trail, which is accessed off Squaw Run Road in the valley. The loop is easy to follow. Going clockwise from the Guyasuta Trail, you'll weave and climb to a road (Trillium Lane).  

Here is the only "tricky" part. You'll see two roads: one with a brick structure splitting the lanes, and another that is cinder with a metal gate across it. Take the metal gate road; there are signs that indicate it is the Lockhart Trail (aka dog walking path). You'll head down the fire road for a hundred feet or so before a sign (on your right) will indicate the trail turns left off the road, down a few stone steps.  Continue on the trail from here.

In general, the trail is really nice and as you make your way around the loop, you'll come to a stretch of large stone steps which are unique. A section of the trail follows along the hillside with a great view in the fall with colors from the trees across the valley and above Squaw Run.
This trail starts off as an intermediate one with inclines, descents, roots, and rocks. About halfway through, the trail will take on more level and uniform terrain.
There are multiple trailheads and road crossings with free parking. Resupply is possible at Cross Fork.

The main access to this trail is at the Cucumber Falls parking lot with a second lot at the end of Kentuck Road. From Cucumber Falls, the trail starts with rocky terrain at the base of the falls, and then follows along the Yough riverfront for approximately a quarter mile. There are chances to stop and enjoy watching rafters make their way around Fern Cliff.

At the mouth of Meadow Run, the trail turns to follow along the stream for a half mile. Here the trail forks, creating the lollipop. Taking the trail to the right will begin the climb to the top of the hill immediately. Taking the trail to the left will follow at the foot of the hill before making the climb. The climb itself is steep and rocky.

The return trip offers another glimpse of rafters on the Yough. The trail doesn't access other trails aside from Great Gorge Trail.

Trail access can be found via one of the multiple connectors around the Iroquois shelter area. The Green Loop shares trail with the Blue Loop for a section.  

There are two distinct sections to this loop: The upper section and the valley section. The upper section is standard dirt singletrack that's well blazed, and well-groomed. The valley section starts and ends with a steep descent and climb. When in the valley itself, the trail becomes more difficult with fallen trees, debris, and multiple stream crossings.  However at the northern end of this trail section you'll be treated by a small waterfall.

This is a short loop through mostly evergreen forest. Part of the trail runs next to Black Moshannon Lake. From this trail, you can follow the Beaver Creek road to access more of the trail system in the Black Moshannon State Park if you are looking for a longer hike.

Trail #15 is long and rocky, so just watch your footing. This trail was originally built by mountain bikers, so at no point along this trail is there any need to climb over large rocks. During the last ice age, PA was the terminus of the ice sheet and this is one of the more southern trails that showcases that geologic feature. There are numerous areas of very large boulders seemingly placed there by the hands of the gods. There are also multiple dead end spur trails that lead to rock climbing areas.

Fish Run Trail starts at the main parking lot of the Wolf Rock trailhead. The first section of trail was built by LHORBA. There is a fun mix of challenging rocky sections gardens and smooth singletrack until the trail makes a left at a T and follows an old service road. This section has grown into a smooth singletrack. 

A few hundred yards before Linn Run Road, the trail will make a 90 degree right and twist and turn until it meets up with the original part of Fish Run. There is a bailout point here on your left where Hickory Flats Rd meets Linn Run Rd. To take the bailout would be a mistake since you would miss arguably the best trail at Laurel Highlands. This original section of Fish Run is level to downhill for about 1.75 miles. The narrow singletrack follows a scenic stream, the namesake of the trail, through rocks and gradual twists and turns on less technical sections. 

You'll pass Hobblebush Trail on your right before continuing the descent to Linn Run Rd. Please be very cautious on the short drop onto Linn Run Rd. The trail is very washed out, loose and steep and there may be cars traveling the road.

When you hit Linn Run Rd. you have the choice of making a left on the road to return to the Wolf Run parking lot to access Picnic Trail or Wolf Rocks Trail or, for a longer hike, cross the road and continue on Fish Run Trail. 

At the road crossing, another leg of the trail continues downhill along the far side of the road. This leg is the remains of the PW&S logging railroad, but is not used because it simply dead ends ahead. The trail to Grove Run stays to the left as a sweeping uphill curve which originally served as a runaway train ramp during those logging days prior to the Park. A couple other small spurs drop off to the right along the climb but these are not used either.

If you continue on the Fish Run Trail, be prepared for rocky sections on a much less traveled trail. The trail will eventually end at a T on Grove Run Trail. A left on Grove Run, a left on Quarry Rd, a left on Weaver Rd and a left on Hickory Flats road will lead you back to Linn Run Rd. just below the Wolf Rocks parking lot. The other option is to stay on Grove Run to Linn Run Campground.

From the parking lot at Mountain Spring Rd, follow the trail to the left fork. The path crosses Elder's Run via a small bridge and continues up the mountain. This trail terminates at Laurel Drive but also intersects with several other trails including the Horseshoe Trail and the Demonstration Plots Trail.
This loop is nearly a point to point, with the capability of jumping on and off the Golf Course Trail (Orange Blaze) at the chapel.

trail_name: AT: Bake Oven Knob - Lehigh Gap
description: Appalachian Trail (AT)

The Neal Thorpe Trail starts at Lock 60 Canal Park.  From the parking area, cross the foot bridge over the Canal and turn left/upriver as if you are on the Upper Schuylkill River Trail.  

Before the trail enters the treeline, a trail sign indicates the Neal Thorpe Trail to the right.  The trail is well established and follows a small gorge upstream.  There are a couple of stream crossings, but each time I have visited, there has been no trouble crossing because of low water or ice.  

Approximately 1/2 mile in, the trail reaches a small open space with a fire pit in it. After this point the trail takes a hard left and climbs up a steep hill with no switchbacks.  Once on top of the hill, the trail is difficult to distinguish from the many other animal and footpaths atop the ravines. Following the largest path (perhaps it's an old logging road) will lead visitors through the trees to the north for approx. 1/4 mile. At this point, the trail will reach an end.  

It has been reported that there is a small path in the narrow section between private houses and steep hillside that allows you to continue  further and rejoin the Upper Schuylkill River Trail farther upstream, but the icy conditions prevented me from searching out the other end.

This trail starts from the parking lot south and heads up the 3/4 mile climb to the beautiful vista overlooking Loyalsock Creek. Once there, continue up to your right and finish the climb. A few more feet and there is another great vista for your viewing pleasure. Work your way across the ridge. Continue down some good descents, then hang a hard right to finish off descending to the gravel road. Head back on the gravel road to the parking area.

This trail is part of the "Mount Joy Trail" cluster. This is the primary path over Mount Joy. The trail is a nice climb/descent with only a few rugged sections. That majority of the trail is crushed gravel surface and is wide enough for two people . The trail starts at the Knox Farm parking area off of Rt 252 in Valley Forge National Park. From the trailhead map in the parking lot, follow the paved Joseph Plumb Martin Trail Northeast until the unpaved Mount Joy Trail .42 miles up.   This switchback will take you on the east side of two soldier bunkhouses.  A path directly up the field on the west side of the bunks is a social trail that cuts the switchback.  Please follow the paved path and help prevent erosion along the unofficial path.

The trail then gradually climbs up through two high points on Mt. Joy, but does not summit them. If you're looking to reach the summit, there are side trails to the top where an observatory used to stand.   Along the way there are several places to look out into Valley Creek and onto the Valley Forge Farms section of the park.  In this section will be General Knox's Quarters (present during encampment), PC Knox Estate (highly modified since encampment), Lord Stirling's Quarters (Modified after encampment) and General LaFayette's Quarters (far to the South-Southwest on the far side of Valley Creek).  


The trail then descends into the valley in which George Washington's Headquarters is situated.  After hiking to the headquarter's end of the trail, add a small bypass look on the return trip by turning left on Mount Joy - East Side Alternate Route.  

A second connector trail, Mount Joy - Joseph Plumb Martin Trail Connector departs the Mount Joy Trail to the East to join up with Joseph Plumb Martin Trail near Artillery Park.

The third option used to be a side loop to an old observatory.  The observatory was removed many years ago and part of the trail has recently been abandoned.  The Mount Joy - Observatory Loop connector still summits Mount Joy, but there is no Observatory and no return loop.  This trail is less maintained, several large steps required at the Mt Joy end of the trail before entering an open field where the observatory had been.  Without the observatory there is no clear view past the trees.  The connector then heads Northeast towards Inner Line Drive and Joseph Plumb Martin Trail.  The original loop is no longer maintained and difficult to pick out.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Nockamixon State Park

As the most popular access to Wolf Rocks, stay alert for other trail users and yield accordingly.  Trail conditions vary with three distinct sections.  Intermediate overall, but with a smooth middle section and a very rocky far section.  All are relatively level with a gradual overall downhill to the overlook. 

This trail starts at the rear parking area of Laurel Summit State Park adjacent to Fish Run Trail. The first section from the trailhead starts with a short rocky stretch and then meanders over rounded embedded boulders through high laurel to the intersection with Spruce Flats/Hobblebush.  

The middle section from Spruce Flats Trail to the Rector-Eddie Road connector is smoother with a few isolated rocks and some optional log obstacles along the sides of the trail. The last section from the connector to the overlook is increasingly rocky but is manageable all the way back to the overlook.

trail_name: Schuylkill River Trail - Conshohocken to Parkersford
description:
The Schuylkill River Trail will cover approimately 130 miles of the Schuylkill River when completed.  At this point, there are several discontinuous sections available.  This section of the trail is from Conshohocken to Parkersford.  For most of the path, this is paved and 4-8 feet wide.  It typically follows the river, although at times it may track straighter than the river and stray from the river's edge.

This section begins in a commercial/industrial section of Conshohocken.  At the start there is easy access to food, beverage and parking.  Just downriver on the trail (to be mapped still), there is a brewery with trail access.

Going upstream from Conoshohocken, you'll pass a blend of urban suburban, and rural landscapes.  The trail will travel through the edge of Norristown, before entering into Valley Forge National Historical Park (A connector to the park is still under construction, although a temporary wooden walkway is available along the US 422 bridge at Betzwoood Access).

In Valley Forge, the trail is wooded.  If it weren't for paralleling US 422, it would be quiet and serene.  After the trail crosses the Perkiomen Creek, one switchback carries the trail down to stream level near the Confluence of the Perkiomen Creek and Schuylkill River.  The trail continues along the bank of the Schuylkill behind an Industrial area of Oaks before another wooded and  isolated stretch up to Reynold's dog park.

At the Dog Park and downriver end of the Schuylkill Canal, the trail takes a hard S turn around the end of the Schuylkill Canal and continues on the riverside/towpath of the Canal (to be more accurate, it's really a navigation, not a canal).  From here until the Route 29 bridge in Phoenixville the trail is mostly grass/crushed stone.  (There is an onroad option of the trail at this point)

At the Route 29 Bridge, the trail crosses the Schuylkill into Chester County, then follows a few road sections behind Bridge Street (filled with popular shopping and dining options).  A recently opened section of trail continues through the gentle slopes and rural areas of Chester County to the trailhead in Parkersford.  A large portion of the Chester County section is a crushed gravel surface.  At this time, the adjacent section of trail has yet to be completed

South Trail traverses the south slopes of Camelback Mountain. The route starts with easy grades in mixed hardwood forest. There are multiple vistas along the way, overlooking ridgelines to the south. 

Just over halfway, the route descends steeply through a couple of switchbacks and then continues on to the North Trail Lower Loop.

Starting at the Boston Ballfield parking area for the Great Allegheny Passage head north on the passage for about 1/2 a mile. While you are getting this nice warm up in pay attention to the big hill to your left, that's the monster you'll soon be climbing. 

Once the gap trail turns into pavement start looking for a left hand trail with a large information board that you'll be turning into. The trail officially begins at the information board. Go past the ruins and when you come to the bridge crossing the creek bear left and continue up the hill. Once you locate the stone stairs you are now at the base of the "witch". And trust me this trail is a witch!

You'll now start switch backing up the hill, frankly I lost count of switchbacks after ten. However, the climb continues on beautiful trail, even if it is very challenging.  Pay attention to the blue diamonds with black arrows, they will guide you up the trail.

The views from the top cliff edge are excellent. 

Trail ends at another informational sign, now all you need to do is enjoy the descent.

The Kentuck Trail can be accessed from three distinct points: (1) the Tharp Knob Picnic Area at the southern end, (2) the Kentuck Campground Wood Shelter at the only road crossing in the middle of the trail, or (3) the Jonathan Run Trail at the northern terminus. These points also denote the distinct "heads" of the trail. 

The southern half of the trail is rolling with a few climbs and descent that can be enjoyed. The northern half is a single hill of 400 feet that is made of loose rock (2" diameter). However, Jonathan Run Trail is a beautiful trail crossing over Jonathan Run several times, which is a 10-15 foot wide stream over little depth.

Note: when exiting the woods heading south to north, you'll exit the woods to a campground road with the wood shelter to your left. Stay on the road, heading up the small incline. The Kentuck Trail juts off the road and immediately begins the descent to Jonathan Trail.

For the most part Mill Run Trail is flat, on loamy soil, with few challenges. Nevertheless, it is a stunning stretch of singletrack notable for its beauty as it courses along Quebec/Mill Run. The trail runs along a camping area that provides an excellent place to eat and relax. 

Also, from Mill Run Trail you can access Miller Trail, Rankin Trail, Grist Mill Trail, Brocker Trail, and Tebolt Trail, so the options are many to extend your hike from here in creative ways. 

The trail has a couple of small stream crossings and several muddy sections all of which can usually be bypassed. Full disclosure, there are a few challenges as the trail briefly ascends the sidehill before dropping down again and then at its southern end it climbs steeply.

This singletrack trail begins with a climb into the forest of Moraine State Park.   The trail is full of roots and small rocks in the opening section and several areas can be swampy if it has rained recently.  

After the opening wooded section you enter a field.  Those familiar with the park will recognize this as the sled riding hill.  This is a very difficult section to navigate as there are no blazes here at all to guide you.  If you look closely you can see where the path winds across the hillside.  If you can't, aim for the bird nesting boxes and keep them just to your right. 

Next, you'll come to a road.  You'll cross the road and continue along the trees away from the road, keeping the trees to your left.   At the crest of the hill, head straight across and you'll see where the path leads down into the trees again.   

This section of the trail offers a view of the lake through the trees during the winter and early spring months.  Further down, the trail you'll pass some cuts that open up the lake view.  

Another road crossing comes up when you get to the Bear Run boat launch area. Signs are present here to keep you on the path. Again, the section after you cross the road is usually muddy. 

After that, you'll come upon signs for the Hilltop Trail.   Stay straight on the path to continue on the Pleasant Valley Trail.  

After another quarter mile or so you'll begin to descend.  As you near the bottom, you'll reach a Y intersection.  The Y signifies the end of the Pleasant Valley Trail, but it connects with the Sunken Garden Trail at this point.   If you go right, you'll be on the Sunken Garden Trail - Long Loop and have a few more miles added to your journey.  Heading left will follow the Sunken Garden Trail back to your vehicle and an open restroom.   

*NOTE*  The Sunken Garden Trail is a loop trail with only one exit so either direction will have you arriving at the same point. 

Following the Sunken Garden Trail - Short Loop will take you past the Rangers Office at the beginning of the park and then down along the lake.  After yet another wet section, a bridge across a small stream takes you close to the lake before returning you to the parking lot just before the Pleasant Valley Trail.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - French Creek

This route is a nice hike through a medium to low density woodland and allows anyone to easily spot flora and fauna that may be present depending on the season. There are no scenic overlooks or anything that is especially remarkable; however, the trail does provide a fairly level and easy path for beginners. Black bears may be present in the area during the summer and fall seasons. Use extreme caution around these wild animals and do not attempt to feed them under any circumstances!

This trail provides a longer more challenging route to the Wolf Rocks overlook or allows the hike to be turned into a loop rather than out and back. This trail dips below the crest of the ridge to offer more elevation change and more rocks than the other routes.

The Reeds Gap Spur Trail begins at the Mid-State Trail junction in Poe Paddy State Park and ends at parking lot A of Reeds Gap State Park. The hiker will join the White Mountain Ridge Trail (WMRT) 2.1 miles after the junction and a steep and rocky climb. 

The WMRT is an out-and-back trail with a small loop at the end where the hiker can take the Devil's Elbow Trail to the road and rejoin the WMRT after a short road hike. Chimney Rock is a highlight of this section. After returning to the RGST, the hiker can expect to cross multiple ridges with steep rocky climbs and descents. You'll take a step back in time at the Bear Gap Picnic area.

Start at the gate right off Old Barbours Access Road. Enjoy a flat hike over some slightly rooty sections with rocks here and there. About halfway, you start to descend through some rockier sections. There will be an intersection at Grandad Trail and then down further an intersection at Shingle Run Trail and Little Grandad Trail.

Roaring Run Natural Area sprawls across the Laurel Ridge mountain side, covering a +1500 foot promenade. The trails in Roaring Run Natural Area are "raw" in the sense that there is minimal maintenance for removing debris and the terrain takes on a similar persona. The trails are rough, full of softball-sized rock and small sticks and debris are plentiful across the trails.

Starting from the Route 31 trailhead parking lot, McKenna Trail starts at the southern end of the parking lot (furthest end from Route 31) following the treeline before entering the woods. Once in the woods, the trail winds its way over two smaller hills before encountering the first major intersection with Painter Rock Trail (note, there are two other trails that intersect McKenna, and they lead to Painter Rock Road trail). Trails are blazed and major intersections are marked with sign posts. To continue on McKenna, stay straight/right to climb the most significant rise on McKenna. At the top, hikers will begin to descend before hiking into North Loop Trail.

There is no mountain biking or horseback riding. Adding to the technical terrain and often steep climbs or descents, the trails are often empty giving hikers solitude, if that's the desire.

You can begin your hikeon the Manor Township segment of the Enola Low Grade Trail at the parking lot on the northern end (ample parking available) or you can loop this route into a hike through Chestnut Grove on the Chestnut Grove Trail.  

This nearly-flat maintained trail is wide enough for walking, running, and biking, offering great views of the Susquehanna River along the way. Keep an eye out for bald eagles, as they can be found on the river looking for a meal.

The full trail is just about 30 miles long, but for its duration it remains similar to the portion described above. The elevation change is slight, but there will be a gentle ascent if you take it as mapped. With many starting and stopping off points, you can make a variety of customized loops, or you can take on its full distance.

Trail #13 is a nice loop with some small rock gardens. This makes for a good short hike from the lower parking lot and back using Trail #5 as the connector. On the more western side, this trail goes by a large hill that this trail circles, but there are a few bouldering opportunities here, if you're feeling like traveling vertically. It could also be considered a preview or practice for Trail #15. The trail has a few rock gardens, but they are much smaller and easier to navigate than what you'll find on Trail #15.

Comment Type:

    self-destructs in 90 days 
 Beta for this Trail or Personal
    Opinion
Appalachian Trail (AT)
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Michaux State Forest

The main trailhead and parking area is located just off Braddock Avenue just before the on-ramp for the parkway in-bound.  The trail as a whole is smooth gravel, with a brief section over concrete.  

The trail starts out with a gentle downhill before leveling off for the remainder of the section prior to crossing Forward Ave.  This section follows closely to the Nine Mile Run, and is surrounded by forest and tall grasses, making it a heat and humidity collector in summer.

You'll come to a small parking lot at Forward Ave and will have to cross to continue.  You'll pass under the parkway, which is at the Squirrel Hill Tunnel for reference.

From here, the trail becomes more scenic, while remaining well groomed with a gravel base.  You'll be faced with slight climb and quarter mile of flat trail surrounded again by tall grasses.  Then comes the 'big dip' which drops down to Nine Mile Run and immediately back up, losing and gaining the same amount of elevation on either side.

The remainder of the trail takes you to Old Browns Hill Road, where if you head down the hill to the Monongahela River, you can access Duck Hollow Trail (a paved rail-trail).

This trail starts from the Orange Trail just north of West Walnut Lane. The trail rolls along paralleling the Orange Trail the entire way. The first 0.1 mile is on the Orange Trail.  Keep an eye out as you hike, as there are many access trails, trail crossings and even road crossings as you head north along the White Trail. There is a very steep hill (though it is short) about 1.8 miles along the trail (if you're heading north). 

At the junction with the Orange Trail about 2.6 miles in, the trail begins to climb to the higher elevations in this valley. Wissahickon Creek will be visible for the majority of the trail when the trees are not leafed out (late fall through early spring). Unlike the Orange Trail which is a singletrack trail, White Trail is wide enough to hike two abreast for the vast majority of its length. A special feature is the Statue of Tedyuscung at mile 4.1. The trail ends at another junction with the Orange Trail and the Laveder Trail. I highly recommend adding the Lavender Trail to your hike as it follows a babbling brook back down to the Orange Trail which is a delightful highlight.

Falls Ravine Trail is the main and most direct fire road climb/descent between upper and lower Frick Park.

Those that enjoy fire roads can have a nice series of loops in the park as well by connecting to nearby trails. While the place is not big, you can easily put a few hours of trail exploration with minimal repetition.
The easy, graded Tranquil Trail fire road runs most of the valley length and connects the Lower Frick parking lot with Frick Park's Point Breeze/Homewood Cemetery park entrance.

The 60-mile long Delaware Canal towpath is a National Recreation Trail that travels between Easton and Bristol. Back in the day, it was used by mule teams pulling boats along the canal. Today this route is used by hikers, runners, cyclists, and bird watchers. 

The route is not technically challenging and gains less than 150 feet of elevation over its entire distance. It has several access points and crosses some diverse and varied terrain. Hikers will enjoy a variety of scenery no matter what portion of the trail they decide to hike. 

For more information about the trail, visit the park's website.

This is a nice and enjoyable trail when the brush is clear, but more often than not it isn't. Every so often a group clears it aggressively, but the brush regrows just as aggressively.

Start at either end, Kidd's Mill or Big Bend. It's generally easy to hike and follow at the start, but sooner or later the thick brush takes over. There are sections that are very wet, depending on how the rain has been, and there are many obstacles and large fallen logs to climb over. It is easy to get lost, but the important thing to remember is that it was once a towpath. So the trail will ideally hike along the manmade ridge next to the canal pools, much like the raised railroad bed of a rail trail.

From New Hamburg, the southern section is generally much more clear.

Mostly level river trail with a few dips for stream crossings. No engineered features, but many natural obstacles such as roots, mud, and loose sections. One old pipe crosses the trail at shallow angles.

Stream crossings are frequent and vary greatly in difficulty. In some cases, the mud is surprisingly deep and can lead to some difficulty navigating through. Make sure your shoes/boots are tied tightly!

The trail splits frequently for horses one direction and foot traffic the other. Follow the horse direction to ford a stream, or the hike direction to cross a narrow bridge with railing.

Fairly picturesque as fire roads go, this 1.8 mile route bypasses a more difficult section of the AT: Wilmington Trail Club (PA). It also connects with Table Rock Spur and Lake Lettini Trail for those wishing to add mileage.

Hikers can either start this trail by hiking from the visitor center at Crow's Nest Preserve along the Chief's Grove Trail, marked by yellow arrows, until you reach the red arrows marking the start of this trail - or you can jump right onto the trail from Harmonyville Road. 

From Harmonyville Road, you'll pass through farmland until you reach the woods, where you'll be surrounded by oak, hickory, tuliptree, beech, maple, and spicebush trees. Nearly extinct American chestnuts sprout from decaying stumps. The trail passes over Northside Road twice along it's loop. You'll see green arrows at two points along the trail, marking the Fox Hill Trail.

trail_name: AT: Mountain Club of Maryland - South (PA)
description: Appalachian Trail (AT)
Moderately trafficked, mostly flat and wooded. A number of side trail options for extending or altering the main loop.

This trail follows an old logging road up to Chestnut Ridge. The road-trace isn't too strenuous, but there are a few steeper sections at the start before the grade backs off for the remainder. Enjoy the tree cover and spacious views this trail affords.

A less frequently used trail in a very popular state park. There are some small rocky sections to navigate along the way and a few stream crossings, too. Overall, there is a great variety of terrain on this short trail.

Located on the southern portion of the park/lake, this trail meanders in nature through forested and new growth areas, not very rugged, but contains rolling uphills/downhills.

Be aware that this trail is shared with mountain bikers. Stay alert while on the trail to ensure your safety and the safety of others.
There are a few places to start this relatively flat and gravel/two-track loop around the reservoir. The loop itself is a good, easy hike, open for all levels.
Can park at airport terminal.

trail_name: Glacier Ridge Trail - Trout Cove Alternate
description:
This section of the Glacier Ridge Trail/North Country Trail is another alternate route that takes hikers along the bank of Lake Arthur before climbing up a hill and descending to the Route 528 Trailhead.

The trail is easily located at the eastern terminus where signposts signal the trail split. Slightly harder to identify at the western terminus, the trail spurs off from the GRT/NCT without any significant signage.  Possibly the easiest way to remember that the trail splits is by using Lake Arthur as the marker. Nowhere else on the GRT/NCT does the trail get so close to Lake Arthur. So, keep this in mind. You'll descend what will seem like the 4th or 5th significant hill, and arrive at Lake Arthur, but the trail will turn and head up a hill within 2 minutes (.1 mile) after reaching the lake. This is where the trail splits, and if you stay along the banks of Lake Arthur, you'll have linked into this alternate route.

This alternate is really nice, providing a change of pace and scenery for the first half of the trail. Finally out of the woods, you'll have the lake and fisherman dotting the banks. However, you'll eventually turn north and climb over 1 mile to the top of the hill before linking back into the GRT/NCT trail.

Old Airport part of the Bavington (Hillman State Park) trail system. Trails are meticulously maintained. Even during the wet months most trails remain pretty dry. 

This section is mostly smooth.

Be sure to check out the Pine Race Track mid way through the trail. If you make a lap on the Pine Race Track, make the first right after you return to the start to continue on the Old Airport Trail.

Starting from the north side of Wildwood Park, this path continues through the park as a nature trail. At the end of the park, the trail turns into a paved path and continues south. Stick close to the sidewalk, especially when crossing under Interstate 81. From there, the Greenbelt continues to its southern terminus, where parking is also available. 

It meanders through beautiful green space and is a relaxing and enjoyable walk.

From the eastern side of Forbidden Drive take the dirt path up into the woods. You'll pass by parts of Philadelphia University and cross under the Henry Avenue Bridge. 

Even though its in the middle of the city, the path seems pretty rustic and secluded and gives you a pretty nice view of the Wissahickon Creek. When you get to Rittenhouse Street, you'll turn left back to the Historic Rittenhouse Town parking lot. 

Add the Lincoln Drive Trail to your loop and get a nice and tough 3mi/5k hike.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Ricketts Glen State Park
This is an old fall line trail that still works for descending or climbing.

From the Ice Rink/VIP lot, go up the hill toward Twin Hills Rd and the trailhead will be on the left, just past the natural gas meter. This takes you on to a nicely rolling trail.  At the next fork in the trail, make a right and head up to, and cross, Twin Hills Rd.  Up the grass toward the pavilions, the trail enters the woods just to the right of the uppermost pavilion.  

The trail will parallel Stoltz Rd. until you near Twin Hills Rd.  Continue out to Twin Hills Rd, make a right, and reenter the woods on the left-hand side of the road.  Once on the trail, bear left and follow this twisting section down to a gas line right-of-way.  Make a sharp left and follow the trail back to Twin Hills Rd.
No fee to enter the state park.

Start from "Confusion Corner" and head down the connector to take a hard left. Climb up and out of the hollow and enjoy about 1.5 miles of doubletrack with great wooded scenery. Once to the intersection, follow the Lance's Trail signs. At this point, it is all singletrack with some rocks. Towards the end, you'll descend quickly, so be sure to watch for the ruts and rocks. Just as the trail starts to flatten out, hang a hard right and climb back out of the hollow. There will be one more small downhill section followed by a steep climb to get back to "Confusion Corner."

    Opinion
The steep climb can be pretty rocky

Middle Ridge is easy to get to and easy to bail from if you are in over your head. The trail is best east to west and seems to get slightly easier in that direction as well. The beginning is a jumble of rocks that you'll have to navigate. 

The trail intersects with several trails that traverse between Hunter Rd and Henstep Valley Trail, so there are always options to shorten your hike. The intersections themselves aren't always marked, but its pretty clear that you want to stay on the ridge and keep following the trail on the spine itself. 

There are a few rock outcroppings along the trail to keep it interesting. At the end, the trail drops off a little steeply, so watch your footing.

This trail begins at the bottom of the paved road if you have parked at the visitor center. It shortly turns to boardwalk, and you'll find several birding huts along the trail next to the lake. Watch out for wildflowers and other wildlife along this trail, and who knows what you'll find! At the end of the trail you'll see Marsh Road that, if you take a left, will lead you back to where you started!

The yellow trail offers a nice loop that connects the red trail with the purple trail. Starting from the  intersection with the Purple Loop and the Panhandle Connector Trail, the trail traverses through a rooty wooded area, continuing south to begin the loop before coming back north on the other side. Over the course of this loop, hikers will end up bisecting the purple trail.

Before getting to the road where the trail comes to an end, the route will continue on its rooty, winding course. All in all, this is a nice short loop.

Entering off Beaver Rd., start with a short 1/2-mile climb through the pine trees followed by a descent through the ferns down to the bridge crossing. Across the stream through the campsite and across Smays Run Trail (forest road), you then begin a 1-mile climb up through the trees before the descent and short rise to Underwood Rd.

Access Info: This trail can be accessed from Beaver Rd or off Underwood Rd.

This trail starts off the Spring Hollow Trail at either end. The southern trailhead can be located at the bottom of the cinder section of trail that leads from the parking lot. Once at the bottom of the hill, the treeline will break to the right, away from the trail, and the entrance to Oak Forest will be a grassy-looking swath cut into the treeline. The northern trailhead has a singletrack dirt entrance and is easily seen from the Spring Hollow Trail.

Starting from the southern trailhead, hikers will immediately start to climb the hill. Once at the top, the trail weaves through the regenerating forest. It should be noted that the trail may be hard to follow as the foliage is not dense, and little undergrowth is present. As hikers make their way across the hilltop to the northern end, there is steep descent back to Spring Hollow Trail.
Land Manager:  Montour Area Recreation Commission

Typically collecting ground and rain water throughout the year, this trail can get muddy in a hurry, with some of the short, but steep'ish, climbs getting really slick.  Starting from the south end (in the woods), you can access the trail at the 5-way intersection.  Look for a small wooden bridge.  

From the north end (blue-slide park) you can access the trail from the paved walking path.  Just look to the tree line for an opening.  There are two.
Land Manager:  Milton S. Hershey Medical Center

Hiking from south to north, you can enter this trail from the Braddock Trail, which runs parallel and above for the length of the trail.  Not much in the way of roots or rocks, but after rainfall, this heavily used trail does show signs of wear and retains water running off from the hillside above.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Laurel Hill State Park

You can hike "Big" Grandad either way. 

Starting from the bottom, you drop down an embankment and cross over the creek. Start your way up, and stay left at the fork. You'll climb through some rooty sections down bottom then you'll get into some rocky areas.

Eventually, you'll cross a bridge on your right then continue upward. There are a few spots that get pretty muddy in the spring and fall that you'll encounter, so use the rocks to your advantage. At the end, there is a pretty steep climb for only 30 yards before you'll intersect with the Brushy Ridge Trail.
Watch out for rattlesnakes and scat on the trail.

There is no parking at the southern end of the trail, but there is parking at the north end. If you don't feel like doing the whole thing, 40 Maples Day Use Area offers parking a bit south of midway between the two. There are restrooms at 40 Maples and the park office/wildlife center.

    Opinion

This alternate route is a shortcut of sorts, but what you save in distance (maybe 0.2 miles) you are subjected to in climb (~100 feet). Heading west to east, the initial climb is significant, but the eastern face of the hill gives hikers room to hike over pretty fair trail. The GRT/NCT shared section follows contours around the hill, and is a more enjoyable section than this alternate route.

Start out at the intersection of Brushy Ridge Trail and head east down Little Grandad Trail. Overall, the trail is pretty tight and has bits and pieces of rocks with a bunch of drops around a foot high. The first hazard you'll encounter is where the trail used to run but now is basically a hole. Watch your footing, and stay left at the roundabout!

After that you'll get into a muddier section; stay right. On the right, you'll find rocks to carry you over the mud and then some log piles as well. Continue down the trail, enjoying some of the east coast rocks PA is known for. At the very end, there is a creek crossing so keep your head up. Once across the creek, you'll run into the bottom of the Grandad Trail.

This is a quick way to get to Flat Road Trail and Old Lewistown Pike (upper end) and Pig Pile Trail (bottom end) from the Greenwood Furnace State Park. There is also a parking area in front of the cell tower near where Pig Pile Trail connects to the road.

Access this trail from Fourth Gap Road and head east at the second intersection that you come to. You'll follow a fence for a little bit, and then continue on meandering through the beautiful scenery on a mixed tread. Enjoy the longer downhill in the middle of the trail, because right afterwards there is a very steep climb hidden on the trail. 

You'll eventually connect onto a road for a short while then cut off the road left to finish up on Mile Run Road.
Steep incline near the start but then evens out for a nice hike, albeit a bit of road noise from Route 33.
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation

Starting from where Gulph Road crosses Valley Creek itself, the Valley Creek Trail initially bends away from the water and passes through some woods. During this first portion of the trail, keep an eye out near where the Colonial Spring Trail branches of to the west. There are interesting ruins of what used to be a bottling company that are still mostly intact. Peeking through the trees to see the remains of the buildings is exciting for visitors of all ages. 

After passing the intersection with the Horse-Shoe Trail, continue back eastwards until reaching the creek again. Follow the creek on this essentially flat trail as in hugs the eastern flank of Mount Misery.  The short and relatively steep Wolfinger Trail heads west uphill. Soon the Valley Creek Trail ends at the Knox Covered Bridge.

Note: bikes and horses are also allowed on this trail, so a little extra caution is advised.

Follow the Red Blazes for the River of Rocks Trail. You can start on the south side of the Lookout Trail and end on the upper portion of the Lookout Trail. It's about 4 miles total that goes down the mountain and then back up it a bit. There are a lot of rocks to navigate along the way, but they are pretty small. Strollers and the like would not be able to make it.

The longest single trail in Gifford Pinchot State Park, the Lakeside Trail follows along the perimeter of the man-made lake (Pinchot Lake). It's a low grade, but can be muddy from time to time. Along the way, enjoy great views of the lake.  The trail also crisscrosses over other trails throughout the park. Some portions are paved, some portions have a gravel base, but most of the trail is dirt and wooded. The trail also passes through the various day-use areas and other recreational stations throughout the park. One portion travels through the park's campground area.
This trail follows the mountain laurel and rhododendron-lined north shore of Long Pine Reservoir. It passes by numerous overlooks of the reservoir and the surrounding mountains.

The Orange Trail at Green Lane is shorter (2.7 mile) but certainly does not lack excitement with constant changes in grade and many obstacles including downed trees, countless roots, dozens of interspersed rocks, and slight turns. The trail is almost entirely under cover in the woods except for a brief road crossing. Navigation is easy and is further simplified through the use of signs and arrows as well as orange paint strokes on trees to direct you along the trail. The trail also loops right back around to the parking lot where you start. Grades were really no larger than 10% but the grade is constantly shifting which keeps you entertained the whole hike.

A loop trail that connects the Family Campground, Crist Ridge Trail, Rock-n-Ridge #1, and Sawmill. 

The loop is mostly dirt and grassy doubletrack. Look for the singletrack section that bypasses the Family Campground.

This route is one of the longer trails in Frances Slocum State Park. It travels through a mix of old fields and pine forest, intersecting stone walls along the way. The trail connects with several other short trails, including Deer Trail and Hilltop Loop Trail.
Appalachian Trail (AT)

trail_name: North Country Trail: Moraine State Park (Glacier Ridge Trail)
description:
Trail access is located at the parking lot for the bike shop. This section of the NCT follows the Glacier Ridge Trail, and shares the bright blue blazes. In general, the trail is well-groomed, but there are sections of loose rock and larger rocks that slow your pace. 

Heading north/east, the trail starts by taking you over Hidden River Bridge before crossing the bike path and N. Shore Drive. Once over the road, you start the first of many climbs. Continue following the blazes over several roads, around one small pond, and past the marina on your way to the end of this section at Route 528, near the bridge crossing over Lake Arthur. 

Once you cross Route 528, you'll be presented with a 300-foot climb to the top of a ridge, which offers a nice view of Lake Arthur in fall and winter when the leaves have dropped. There are several stretches of open space as you climb which also give glimpses of the lake. The next 5 miles are similar to the first 8. You'll make 3 climbs along singletrack trail which is primarily smooth with occasional sections of loose rock. You'll recognize the end of the trail when you reach the Jennings Environmental Center and a uphill slope of flower beds. The NCT continues on to Allegheny National Forest, and all the way to the New England states, but Jennings Environmental Center marks the end of the Glacier Ridge Trail.

Note, if you head south from the bike shop parking lot, the trail continues for approximately a mile before dumping hikers out at the intersection of Burnside Road and W. Park Road. The NCT continues to McConnell's Mill State Park using Burnside Road and Johnson Road. In McConnell's Mill the NCT follows the Slippery Rock Gorge Trail.

trail_name: AT: Mountain Club of Maryland - North (PA)
description: Appalachian Trail (AT)
