Park at the office next to the lake. 
Follow lake trail signs. You'll cross the dam and there will be some brief dirt road hiking. A woods hike up and down hills comes out at an environmental center. There is a brief hike on a boardwalk through a woodland, back to car.

Access the trail from Raccoon Park Road (west trailhead) or from the Beach Trail and beach area (east trailhead).  

Starting from the west, the trail climbs and dips along easy trail with few obstacles aside from common roots and rocks. This trail also acts as an alternative to avoid Heritage Trail or Forest Trail to reach the Raccoon Lake dam parking area.

Trail #12 is the nicest trail from the lower parking lot to the fire tower. The other routes that are as direct are access roads. This trail has a few intermittent wetland areas with a few long, ground-level bridges. There is one short, steep part with a few boulders to squeeze between, but no climbing is required.

Concrete Block is a singletrack trail connecting Roller Coaster and the lower section of Iron Gate. You can enter the trail from the Iron Gate side between the bridge drop and the clay pipe. 

The trail can be accessed from Roller Coaster after crossing to the west side of the Firelane Trail Extension. You'll come to a fork with a sign for the Roller Coaster trail where the roller coaster trail continues left and the concrete block trail connects on the right.

This connector climbs from near the Horse Stables to the southern tip of the Purple Loop. You can use the Stable Connector from behind the horse stables to access it as well; this trail is great for looping from Zig Zag #12 back to the Purple Loop.

Miller Fields Access Road is a dirt/gravel access road used to enjoy the trails of the Little Bear area. From this trail, you can access Brushy Ridge Trail on the west side or connect to Dunwoody Access Road on the east side.

The scenic 2.3-mile gravel/cinder trail is flat, wide, and well maintained. The area on either side of the trail is fairly open, but there is plenty of shade from the larger trees to escape a hot day. It runs along the north shore of the Schuylkill River with views of the water at different points. There is a small parking area at the east end of the trail off of old Gibraltar Road (20 cars). Additional parking can be found at Trout Run Sports Complex off of Neversink Road with access to roughly the midpoint of the trail.
Mid State Trail (MST)

The major trails in this area are blazed, minor trails are not. The vegetation is sometimes overgrown here, especially in later summer. Most trails can be used in both directions. The section that parallels the Allegheny River is on the ridge, so be careful. 

There are plenty of parking opportunities and you can drop in on trails in numerous places. The park has running water except during the winter months.

Red blaze trail is nicer when hiking in a counter-clockwise direction, as the downhills are longer and mellower. Many other trails that connect to this one so you can string loops for a longer hike.

Mostly a mix hardwood forest, some areas of evergreens, and an occasional field.

Start out by taking a right off the Remington Access Road and head down to the corner and turn left. 

Enjoy some doubletrack with very gentle grade for a mile or so, and then cross over a couple of bridges and enjoy the view of the creek. Work your way up the grade to the switchback that leads you back left. The trail starts to turn into some dirt singletrack at this point. Enjoy the meandering trail as it makes way across the side of the mountain. About halfway across the mountain, the trail starts descending.
This trail connects Little Cherry Run Trail to the main park.

From Ohiopyle, hike upstream on the Great Allegheny Trail for about 100 yards to the Middle Yough Takeout. Sugarloaf and Baughman Trail start on your right side. Stay right at the fork immediately after you get on the singletrack to climb Sugarloaf Trail. It's a steep (in places) ascent to the top of the mountain. The trail can be a little rocky and rugged in places as well.

This trail runs from Washington's Headquarters area to the abandoned Valley Forge Park Train Station. It follows the Schuylkill River and passes behind Washington Memorial Chapel. Most of the trail is easy with one section of switchbacks. This section can easily be replaced with a easier rolling path by taking the side trail towards Varnum's Woods.  

This is not a super scenic trail, but it gets you away from the crowds on the main loops. This trail is popular for horses and mountain bikes and, at times, tracks closely to the railroad tracks.

The trail connects with the Joseph Plumb Martin Trail and will directly connect to the Schuylkill River Trail once the Sullivan Bridge is completed across the Schuylkill River.

The Turkey Hill Trail takes you from the Susquehanna River up to the Chestnut Grove highlands back down to the river valley. The trailhead is also the trailhead for the Low Grade Trail, which can be used as the return route since both are not loop trails. A short steep hike to the highlands takes you past the large windmills through woodlands with great views of the Susquehanna.

The trail dips to Mann's Run (crossing is on rocks) and ascends again, where it soon emerges at the edge of the Chestnut Grove Natural Area meadows. Highlights include a seasonal waterfowl at the large pond at Chestnut Grove, and often merlins, kestrels, and northern harriers can be seen hunting over the meadows. Currently, the trail descends back to the river via a short, steep hillside hike.

trail_name: South Park Connection to Montour Trail
description: Trail Connecting Corrigan Dr to Montour Trail.  This trail starts at Sesqui Dr and Corrigan Dr.  It goes uphill past the duck pond to the model airplane field, then down into Sleepy Hollow.  This is a fun path for ascending out of Sleepy Hollow.  The trail surface is crushed asphalt.
Short moderate hike to a lovely waterfall!

The trail starts from the parking lot, follow the blue blazes. The trail is easy, flat, and wide but at times is marked in a confusing manner. Many trails that lead to it are also blazed blue, so you may come to intersections where all four trails are blazed blue. Hopefully this app will help you pick the correct one.
Heisley Valley Road is an access road used to get to the Heller Reservoir. The trail starts out gravel but turns into grassy doubletrack before ending at a gate where you'll have to turn around.

The trail is accessible from a parking lot at the southern terminus, a parking lot at Cucumber Falls, and a short hike along the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) from a parking lot near the northern trailhead.  

The trail is very level with no obstacles. It is made of crushed limestone aggregate and is enjoyed by walkers, runners, and a few children on bikes.

While there are not great views of the Yough below, Cucumber Falls more than makes up for it. The falls are made up of a single waterfall with many very little falls leading to the Yough. At the base of the major waterfall is a natural wade pool. The water will be chilly year round.

Trail is in state game lands so be sure to wear orange, especially late fall and winter. No facilities at the parking lot but the interstate exit is less than two miles away with gas station and several fast food places.

From it's start at a junction with the Valley Creek Trail, the Horse-Shoe Trail climbs steadily, paralleling the braided Colonial Springs. The wooded landscape may offer a few glimpsed views. Also hidden in the trees, are the ruins of an old bottling plant, and sharp eyes can still spot the stone walls.  

Continue uphill, sometimes steeply before reaching an intersection with the Mount Misery Trail. To stay on the Horse-Shoe Trail, continue right (westwards) over easier ground along a ridge. About 0.2 miles after the junction, the trail crosses into private land, finally ending at East Forge Mountain Road atop Mount Misery.  

Note: Horses are also allowed on this trail, so please be courteous to your fellow trail users.

Starting at the parking area on Stump hall head down the Skippack Creek. This is fairly flat until you get to the bend where you'll start a steady uphill and then a steep uphill over some wooden bridges. This is a really nice pine forest and the terrain can be pretty cool especially in the winter. 

After you get to the top of the hill, you'll start a steady downhill and follow Skippack Creek around until you get to Water Street. Follow Water Street by hiking on the street (watch those cars) or hiking along Skippack Creek. Take a right over a new bridge and down an embankment to the right. This section of trail is poorly marked and not well worn, but you'll eventually follow a stream/runoff uphill to a bridge. Go over that and link with the Mill Race Trail.

trail_name: Horseshoe Trail: Eagle Rock to Ash Lane
description:

Land Manager:  DCNR - Hickory Run State Park
Top Mountain Trail is very rocky throughout with a couple of steeper climbs. Most of the grades aren't too bad but it is quite rugged.

This trail starts out from an intersection with the Appalachian Trail. It descends along the ridge to Miller's Gap where a modest uphill begins over roots and rocks. It continues along the Blue Mountain Ridge with a little bit of gentle grade and smoothness. The short downhill to Lamb's Gap can be a bit steep; watch out for erosion control barriers. Cross Lamb's Gap and get into the most rugged section with a sharp downhill over some serious rocks. There is a small step down in there if you like. Continue slightly downhill through some older forest canopy for a pleasant hike down to a creek crossing. After crossing a number of dead trees that have fallen across the trail. you get another downhill to Tower Road. The best parking lot is at Lambs Gap Road. The Darlington Trail is maintained by the Susquehanna Appalachian Trail Club,  satc-hike.org/

After passing the Model Airplane Field on Montour Trail Ext., you'll climb a short hill and see a trailhead dropping to the right down the hill.  Follow this all the way to the bottom and make a left onto the gravel road.  

Immediately after crossing the stream, make a right to climb to the top of the ridge.  At the top, the trail is a combination of singletrack and doubletrack. Continue south until it drops you back out on Montour Trail Ext.

This small grass path loop offers a beautiful poetic hideaway off the main path. Butterflies are in abundance in season, and koi fish can be spotted in a small man-made pond from an artistic arched footbridge. Tall grasses and wildflowers make great hide and seek cover for the little ones. It is managed and maintained as a "wild" garden, a great spot to relax, snap pictures, and capture the best of each season. It is especially beautiful in the late summer and mid-fall.

This loop is located less than a mile from the bike rental parking off of the limestone path of North Country Trail. Signs marking it are located on the left side. It is wheelchair accessible, but wheelchairs may need assistance with the soft limestone. The loop itself is a wide grassy path.

Take this trail in either direction as part of the trail network near Lake Chestnut. This route connects to Boulder Line and Fernmoss Trail.

Little Bear Creek Road is completely gravel. Start from the various parking lots on the west end and get a good climb in before enjoying some beautiful trails. The whole climb from bottom to top is roughly 6 miles.

Start at the intersection with Charcoal Flats and wind your way uphill. The grade starts gradually but becomes fairly steep for a short distance.  At the ridge, you'll intersect with a trail where you'll head right (left takes you to private property).  Depending on the season, you'll now have a great view of State College to your left as you traverse the ridge for a short distance. 

The trail then drops incredibly steeply and must be walked. Use trees and the attached ropes to get down the cliffs on this precipitous trail. There are no technical climbing skills required but be careful, especially if wet!

As mapped, the trail starts from Burma Trail, just east of the parking. Gradual downhill to east with a few more challenging rocky sections. Westbound uphill leg follows old logging railroad grade though evergreens. 

It crosses Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail 2x (Yellow blazes). The segment west of the road starts with rocky section leading to a short climb to the plateau and connection to Towhee Trail.
Find out more about the flora and fauna of this trail on the Ricketts Glen State Park website.

Trail access is located either from the dam parking lot or Nichol Road at the northern terminus. From the dam parking lot, the trail has a small climb from below the dam to above, where the trail arrives at the intersection with Heron Trail.  

The trail continues and is rather flat following the wetlands edge before starting a switchback up the hillside entering the woods. The remaining trail stays above the wetlands in the woods, but gives plenty of views of the wetlands and Traverse Creek which runs through the wetlands.

The trail has small roots, potential for mud, and a few climbs in the 5-10% range.
This is the main connecting trail between Lockhart Trail and the parking lot. Also, following Squaw Run Road, you have access to the Trillium Trail system.
Mid State Trail (MST)

The Sand Spring Trail is a relatively flat loop. It can be done in either direction. The route travels through a mixture of hemlock forest and open boggy areas with a couple of creek crossings.

The east and south side of the routes have long straight sections, leftovers from old railroad grades. This trail has good opportunities for wildlife viewing.

Similar to West Shore Trail, East Shore Trail has plenty of rocky and rugged challenges. The route has a few short ups and downs and travels through moderately dense forest with open understory. The trail is a narrow single lane trail

The largest single loop within Beechwood Farms Nature Reserve, this trail starts and ends at the parking lot. Progressing counterclockwise, the trail begins with a stretch of doubletrack grass trail as it enters deeper into the woods.

Once into the woods, the trail turns to a tighter, more singletrack design, with plenty of roots and a few fallen trees creating a slightly more challenging section. One significant climb breaks up the trail, about mid-way, asking hikers to give a little more effort, before exiting the woods at the 4-way intersection with Meadowview Trail and Upper Fields Trail. The trail crosses many of the other trails in the reserve, making it a sort of freeway of the trail system.

As you near the final stretch of the trail, hikers will enter a thick field and begin a descent back to the pond and eventually the parking lot.
Parking is only available at the Champ Boulevard Parking Lot at the south end of the trail

Starting from the trailhead parking off Old Ingomar Road, the trail heads downhill towards the trail underpass. This is a very useful and much safer way of crossing Babcock Blvd.  

From there, the trail winds around the base of the hill at North Park Pool before connecting with a fire road cinder connector and the Pine Creek Hill Trail (White/Orange) and Ball Field Hill (White/Yellow) trails.
Land Manager:  York County, PA - Parks and Recreation

Extending beyond the former gas well at the end of the northern segment of Silvermine Trail, the southern segment changes from dirt road to singletrack.  Grade changes are gradual but surface conditions vary abruptly.  The most extensive rocky section extends either side of the Hemlock intersection and a couple lesser ones are scattered along the trail.  

Isolated rounded embedded boulders are encountered all along with a longer stretch of low rounded boulders north of the Hemlock intersection.  Other segments are smooth and rolling.

The Orange Trail is the lower loop in Bird Park which begins and ends in the parking area on the western side. It mostly runs along the hollow. The trail is well maintained with interesting variability in terrain and slope.

This short trail can be accessed (among other ways) via the Chickadee Trail as part of a loop from the AT starting at the Old Forge Picnic Area. The trail can be best described as a singletrack through a mixed hardwood forest. Heavy storm damage rendered the trail impassable throughout 2022 (even with a GPS track) but the trail was cleared and fully blazed (red) as of March 2023.

trail_name: Mrs. Albert S. F. Kiester Trail
description:
This trail can be accessed from the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) trail with a short hike from the nearby parking lot, or from the Kentuck campground, by way of the Kentuck Trail.

Starting from the GAP, the trail begins climbing immediately, having to cover roughly 450 feet of elevation gain in just under a mile. Some sections of are steep, while others offer opportunity to gain a little lost time. Most of the trail covers somewhat rocky terrain and this can impede your momentum when hiking a steeper section.

There is a single fork in the trail which is well marked with a sign pointing campers to the right and trail users to the left.  Stay left to reach Kentuck Trail.

This trail is a long doubletrack that is an easy hike. Lots of small loose rocks is the only challenge you'll encounter. This trail follows the northernmost border of the area and is wide with no real challenging features. The most notable use for this trail would be the wide views of the forest with the chances to see wildlife. Keep a watchful eye open for mountain bikers because they can carry a good bit of speed along this trail.
The West Shore Trail is rocky and twisty, basically just a lot of rugged fun. The route is easy to follow and has a few access points to the lake. The trail is very narrow and muddy in spots

Explorer Lodge Trail veers left where the Horseshoe Trail veers right and continues as singletrack until it passes through a switchback and climbs to the top of the hill where it opens up into a doubletrack fire road. 

It connects to many other trails and eventually ends on South Camp Road. A main artery in Camp Mack's trail network!

This dead end trail takes users to a boardwalk overlook of the scenic Spruce Flats Bog which contains a number of rare and unique plants.  Display plaques provide more detailed information.  This is a popular trail for those visiting Laurel Summit State Park, which is surrounded by Forbes State Forest. The Picnic Area Trail starts part way back this trail, on the right.

Turn off of Raccoon Mountain Trail at the Yellow Diamond markers. This trail is marked for CCW as the main direction.  Either way you decide to take this loop, you'll have a tough climb followed by a wide open downhill. 

After a nice spillway you'll hit a set of old foundations; take a deep breath and sip of water because at the next marked intersection, the climbing begins. Right is the Upper Bower Field Trail and left is Lower (less elevation and much shorter). Take the right and push yourself up to the metal gate which you'll currently have to go around and then continue to the top.  

There is a marked singletrack connector at the top before heading back down. Unfortunately, there is another gate to make your way around before the descent. The descent is marked with directional arrows where needed.  After the foundations, you'll find the intersection with Lower Bower where you'll want to take a right along the stone walls. You'll end up on the common connector and return to Raccoon Mountain Trail..

If you choose the Lower Bower Connector during the climb, you'll have a much shorter climb. Follow this CCW just as the Upper's description and enjoy.  Lower Bower Connector actually connects both sets of really cool building foundations.

Another must do trail segment especially if this is your only visit.  The northern segment dips along the downhill side of Silvermine Trail.  It includes numerous log crossings, a short rock section, and a short but steeper climb. There are several boulders adjacent to the trail providing alternate lines and play spots.

Outcrop crosses Silvermine Trail about midway, offering an alternate access/bailout point.  Users will encounter a bouldery climb through the outcrop after crossing Silvermine Trail. The rest is fairy level with a couple boulder crevices to hike through along with more log crossings and boulders. The trail ends with a gradual rocky descent reconnecting to Silvermine Trail at the former gas well site.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest

This trail follows the roadway to give you the option to loop back from the end of the Marsh Trail to the beginning. The roadway is not paved but is a wide doubletrack suitable for families. It is a great alternative to make the Marsh Trail a loop hike!

This is a short connector between Trail #1 and Trail #15 with a few steep rocky sections. There is only one spot that is really tricky about midway down to Trail #15. There are some ruins along the way of a former summer home that formerly was just outside the property.

This trail is part of the Central Mountain Trail. It connects Mohn Mill Road to Gap Road through the woods versus traveling on Midstate or Pipeline Road (gravel).  

It's a nice intermediate trail through some really tall pines and mixed forest. With barely a rock or root, this will be a great place for a beginner to get some experience hiking singletrack.

Using this trail in either direction is fine. The opening from Mohn Mill has a gate to go around, and the opening from Gap Road is next to the telephone pole. The trail entrance on that side isn't very wide in an effort to reduce hoof or quad traffic. This trail is blazed in red.

Please do not take the border trail that is marked in white and orange. That is not part of our trail. Basically, if you hike north, take two rights, and you'll be fine.
Start at the top of Governor Dick State Park (observation tower). Take the wide gravel path (Trail 1) down to Trail 4 entrance.

This trail is typically used to go uphill because the other side of Red Run Trail is much too steep to hike up. 

This trail starts at the same place as the other side of Red Run Trail, but as soon as you head up, on your left is the beginning of this trail. Get your legs ready as it is very steep, and the uphill won't end until you reach Camp Conly Access Road.
Steep trail going from Gas Well level to Dark Hollow Run Trail.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Black Moshannon State Park

Start at Sunset Park and head down the hill on the paved path. You'll hike by a couple trailheads onto dirt singletrack into the Penn State Arboretum. Turn right at the bottom of the hill onto the packed slate gravel Bellefonte Rail Trail. This continues for four miles in one direction, passing by farms, going under highways, behind neighborhoods, and across a golf course. The four mile trail finishes in a long stretch through the woods. This can get fairly muddy--be warned. Once you reach the end, turn around and head back!

Hammer Creek Trail is a doubletrack that enters from the red bridge on Pumping Station Road and follows the Hammer Creek until climbing up to Explorer Lodge Road. Nothing technical.

Overall, a good, easy way to gain some altitude.

Park in the parking lot (it's quite big) and take a look at the map that is posted there. Go through the gate and just keep hiking! You'll cross a wooden bridge before arriving at an intersection. Go to the left to follow the Musser Gap Trail. If you go right, you'll hike the Frog Hollow Trail instead. This part of the trail is a bit inclined but doable. You'll arrive at another intersection (the second intersection); take it left again. If you go straight, you'll be hiking the Mountain Mist Trail. 

After a little while, you'll arrive at another intersection. Here, this trail is crossed perpendicularly by the Mountain Mist Trail. Keep hiking straight if you want to follow the Musser Gap Trail.

If you decide to go back, you could go to your right (following the Mountain Mist Trail). This path will take you to the second intersection that you encountered before, forming a mini-loop. CAREFUL HERE! Following the Mountain Mist Trail requires you to turn right at some point (it's marked but you might not see the entrance). You'll know that you have missed the turn to the Mountain Mist Trail if you see the signal that says "No hunting, trapping, hiking is permitted before this point".

To continue on the Musser Gap Trail, continue to follow it through the intersection with the Mountain Mist Trail to reach the trail's end in a junction with the Mid-State Trail (MST).
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation

Bruce Lake Trail begins as an old woods road, eventually narrowing to singletrack. Near the south end of the trail, you'll encounter some wet and swampy areas.

Overall, the trail is rocky with beautiful surrounding forest. There's a mix of conifers, hardwoods, dense rhododendron and blueberry patches.

Furnace Creek Trail is a short, blue blazed trail which runs from the Appalachian Trail (AT) at the top of the ridge down to the AT at the bottom of the ridge. The AT heads uphill to the Pulpit and Pinnacle, while this trail connects the top and bottom as it runs along Furnace Creek.

The trail can be accessed from Hamburg Reservoir parking lot by taking Reservoir Road uphill past the Windsor Furnace site and the Hamburg Reservoir itself before entering the woods to run uphill alongside Furnace Creek in a hemlock forest.  

At the top, it meets the AT near an open grassy field used as a helipad. Heading to the right on the AT will take one to the Pinnacle.

This trail is a can be used to make a nice loop with the AT: Blue Mountain Eagle Climbing Club - West (PA) to see Pulpit Rocks and the Pinnacle.

The trail follows the dirt bed of an old woods road from the Long Pine reservoir southwest passed the Hosack Run Trail to the AT (Appalachian Trail) near Caledonia State Park. It passes through a typical mixed hardwood forest, with stands of Rosebay Rhododendron near the mouth of Dark Hollow.  Although there are no views and few other outstanding features along this trail, it is particularly useful for making loop options with the Appalachian Trail.

Get a fun hike in on this nice and hilly singletrack with just enough uphill and downhill to give you a rollercoaster of a ride. One or two climbs and just the right amount of rocks add enough entertainment to make this a worthwhile jaunt. Watch out for the occasional biker and keep your eyes open for the orange blazes, but don't worry too much because this trail is well marked and easy to follow. This is just one of many trails in the park and is easy to connect to add some distance.

This singletrack trail travels alongside Squaw Run starting from Squaw Valley Park and ending at McCahill Park.

Accessing the trail from Squaw Valley Park, take the Squaw Valley Footpath until you reach the open stretch of field behind the children's play area. Hike toward Fox Chapel Road, and the singletrack will be on your right, and is obvious.

The trail winds along dirt and grass sections. Because the trail is lightly traveled, the grass sections may not be as obvious, but there is little room to move as you are often between the road and Squaw Run in those grass sections.

You'll cross a "wood" arched bridge right before the end of the trail. From the bridge, you'll hike along grass first on the right side of the road, and then left side, crossing at the intersection. The trail ends at the following intersection.

This trail starts near the intersection of the Commissary Trail and Sulivan Street.  Just before you reach Sullivan Road at the end of the Commissary Trail, look left for an unnatural looking berm rising up.  (It will be between a small footpath and a larger footpath with yellow posts).  

Ascend the berm and you'll find yourself along the top of a wall built to impound water pumped from the Schuylkill River. The berm was created as part of the first large scale river cleanup effort in the United States.  In the Late 1940's and early 1950's, Pennsylvania and the Army Corps of Engineers dredged and cleaned the Schuylkill River in an effort to remove large amounts of polluting coal silt.  This wall is part of Impounding Basin #21, built to contain the large amounts of coal laden water that were removed from the Schuylkill River.  Inside the basin is a large stone weir which allowed silt to settle and water to return to the river.

Atop the basin is a small footpath.  Aside from a slight grade at the entry point the remainder of the trail is level.  There is a lot of understory growth including thorns to navigate along the way.  The remnants of this berm end at the Commissary Trail

One of the many trails winding through French Creek State Park, this trail makes its way through the hilly terrain of French Creek and is a wider, relatively smooth trail that is not highly technical. No major ruts or erosion were noticed, providing the opportunity for a nice hike through pleasant Pennsylvania woods. 

When I was there in late fall, there was not much dense underbrush, and you could see pretty clearly throughout the woods which are mostly deciduous. There were some laurel as well. The trail is primarily soft dirt with occasional rockier sections. The trail is marked with green blazes and accessible from a few points within the park, including the Scotts Run Lake area, making it a good connector or start to one of the many other blazed trails in the area. It is a multi-use trail with bikers, and there is hunting allowed.

This trail is a personal favorite year round. It features abandoned house and roads from the 1800's. This is a special treat, and this is definitely the road or trail less travelled. The end of the trail hooks up with Vaughn's Trail.

Starting at parking lot #1 (free parking) you head out on the old railroad bed. This trail roughly parallels the creek and has nice views year round. This area only has hiking/running access so you won't see many people out here which is nice. You have access to the Wendel Cassel Trail, the Charles Bailey Trail and the Edwin Leid Trail.
Mid State Trail (MST)

Follow an abandoned road for a short period until you veer off to the left.  Follow this for a bit until you start a steady decline down to the creek.  Fishing along here is fairly popular.  Loop around and continue back to the road that you started on.

The trail can get fairly overgrown in the late summer.

The trail is short and simple. It follows Squaw Run the length of the trail prior to crossing at a "must-get-wet" section. You can connect with the Trillium Trail - Upper Trail and Trillium Trail - Falls Trail for a longer hike.

The Dimeling to Maderia Trail is a scenic route that winds along Clearfield Creek. The trail's surface is cinder and makes for an easy hike in either direction, though if you travel south to north (as mapped) there is a steady slight descent to aid hikers.

Watch for a multitude of other users like cyclists and motorized vehicles.

Starting from the second loop on Laurel Run Road where there is a small parking area, head west.  The trail will follow the outline of the hillside.  There is a series of rock gardens and a bench followed by three long narrow bridges over wet areas.

There is a small gravel parking lot at the end of a driveway just past the Shop n' Save that is relatively hidden off Rt. 21. After parking, the trail begins by crossing a bridge over a stream to access the trail. The trail winds across a river at several points, but is relatively flat and devoid of obstacles. There is a point where you can diverge from the main trail and access the stream. In the spring, there are berries everywhere!
Mid State Trail (MST)

Park at the loop where there are a few grills and pavilions for cooking, then take the trail down to the left next to the Skippack Creek and to the bridge.  The trail can be poorly marked at times, but if you follow the creek you'll be fine.

Head up the Mill Race Trail Campground Connector, close to the road, cross over another parking area and you'll be back in the campground area!
Coming off Laurel Run Rd this one-mile climb takes you up to the entrance to Old Laurel Run Trail at the gate 1/2 way up or to  New Laurel Run Trail at the top.

Please note this area, especially around Lenape Lake, is crisscrossed with many un-blazed trails. A map or the Hiking Project mobile app is highly recommended in order to make sure you are heading in the desired direction.

The Musser Gap Greenway is a great multi-use trail with a gravel surface that traverses beautiful fields to reach a parking area and the trails around Musser Gap. From Whitehall Road, just follow the path—it's impossible to get lost.

The first half of the trail is quite easy as you hike between corn crops and a small group of trees. The path takes you to a farm where you have to turn right. The incline gets intense once you pass this location! Keep an eye on the trail here, as deer are normally grazing in the nearby fields.

At the end of the trail, you'll cross a bridge. Look to your right to enjoy pleasant pastoral views of a farm with a small pond, ducks, a fountain, and beautiful decorations.
Land Manager:  Lancaster County - Parks and Recreation

The trail is known by its namesake, a spring that empties out into a bathtub. It's accessed via the first right turn after entering the woods north of the pigeon shelter. There is an alternate trail Drop to 4 Corners that runs above this trail (the second right turn after the pigeon shelter) which is a more mountain bike focused route with winding switchbacks.

It's a mostly doubletrack trail from Pigeon Shelter area (the end of the Golf Course Trail) to Fall Line Trail that connects to Brown Rd. It does narrow to singletrack in the lower section. Alternatively, there is a short blazed connector to the ice rink which is useful to connect to the Rainbow and Pfundstein Red-Blue Trail after crossing Pearce Mill Rd.

This trail tends to drain poorly in the lower lying areas between the ice rink and the Fall Line Connector Trail and may often have mud in these spots. This trail is also marked as a horse trail as well.
Mid State Trail (MST)

This is a gravel rail-to-trail route that is mostly fine gravel with some sections of pavement. There are several options for parking along this route. 

More info about the SRT can be found  here.

Specific info for Pottstown to Reading can be found  here.
A relatively flat hike around a farm. There is a short section through woods with a stream. Park behind the Kemblesville post office near the recycling bins at the Franklin Township buildings.

Core Creek Trail is a network of singletrack that surrounds the east side of Core Creek.

This trail has very few climbs making it an easy trail for the beginner or intermediate hiker. The surface is mostly smooth, but there are a few logs that vary in height, keeping things exciting. There are plenty of ways to navigate around any obstacles. 

Keep an eye out for a couple of narrow and long boardwalk bridges, as these can be a bit slippery after rain. This is a relatively safe trail for everyone to explore. Enjoy the relaxing hike as you make your way along Core Creek and Lake Luxomborg.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - French Creek
Land Manager:  PA DCR - Promised Land State Park

The purple loop trailhead is from the paved road/walking path near the parking lot for the mansion.  

The trail rolls through some valleys and climbs over some hills, but nothing too tough.  The trail is dirt singletrack, pretty smooth with a few pockets of mud, mainly in the valleys and only after rain.  You'll cross a gas line gap in the trees, but other than that you'll be under canopy of tree cover the entire time.

This trail is part of the Montour Woods Conservation Area. The Oil Well Trail begins from the Hassam Road Trailhead and and meanders along in an east/west orientation to the Downing Drive Trailhead. This one can be taken in either direction, and the way is easy navigation either way. 

Follow the easy, rolling trail from west to east, and you meet up with the Meeks Run Trail. From either end of the Oil Well Trail, you'll be able to access other trails in the area. The Moon Township Community park is located to the west, and the Montour Woods Conservation area is located to the southwest, making route building possible and recommended.

The trail starts just off of SR 554 and heads right up the mountain. This trail is very challenging due to the steep grade and unrelenting uphill. At the Summit Trail, the trail continues north into the Williamsport Watershed.  

If you are looking for a nice 5k loop (aka - the Coathanger), there is an old road grade that parallels 554 that starts at the end of Summit Trail and will connect to the bottom of Culbertson. This loop is completely located within DCNR managed land.

While maps of the area may show the trail continuing further to the north, the northernmost section heads onto private land and has not been maintained in years.

The trailhead is easy to find and there are no wrong-turns on this trail that twists and weaves through the forest. At times taking you very close to Lackawanna Lake, which you can catch glimpses of between the trees.

Very simple loop hike with scenic views of Solebury Township. Parking is limited and is under review for improvement. The open area is part of North Pointe Park, but this area is bordered by private property. It is also used for hunting during certain parts of the year.
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation
Appalachian Trail (AT)

Take caution crossing Rt. 26, especially at Jo Hays Vista.  Camping is prohibited within the Penn State Stone Valley Forest property.  Make sure to camp only on Rothrock State Forest property if using the trail as an overnight backpacking trip.  Common parking areas include Jo Hays Vista, Woodcock Trail parking area within Stone Valley Forest, and Shaver's Creek Environmental Center.  Do not park at Shaver's Creek Environmental Center if hiking in late afternoon, past dark or doing an overnight.  They close the gate after 5:00pm daily.

There is not much to this trail. Yet, it is as memorable as any other trail in the park. 

The trail can be accessed from several trails: Chestnut Path, Laurel Trail, Cabin Trail, Bridle Path, Waterfall Connector, or the Butterfly Fields. 

The trail begins by passing a stone structure missing a roof and much of its walls, with grass and vegetation growing all around it. Once past the house, the trail makes a very steep dip to a stream bed. There are small trees to grasp as you descend, but hikers should take care not to rely too heavily on them as this could potentially damage the trees. A long stretch of stone steps follows, which take you back up the hill, maybe 50 feet, before the trail connects with Chestnut Path and the Butterfly Fields trail system.

This trail runs between the River Trail Trail parking area, past the Walnut Hill Barn and Walnut Hill Desilting Basin, through some wetlands, and reconnects with the River Trail.

From the parking area at the River Trail, follow the River Trail briefly and look for a trail to the left.  Follow this path to the left until it connects to a gravel road, which will be marked with 2 yellow bollards. Turn right on the gravel road.  Next up on your right is the entrance to a trail on top of the impoundment. This is part of the Walnut Hill Desilting Basin trail.  Ignore it for now and continue on the gravel road.

Continue through the gate and follow the road to the left.  As you clear the treeline to your right, there will be a trailhead sign on the right and parking on the left.  You may wish to just park here and skip the gravel road section of the trail.  The trail goes east into the field. A well worn path is obvious.  It will turn right into the trees on the far side of the berm forming the impounding basin.  From here, the path remains obvious but not as well maintained.  Be aware of washout and mud.  The trail will cross a bridge before turning right and reconnecting with the River Trail, which makes for a very pleasant loop. 

An optional extension of this trail follows the power line cut until another connector allows you to turn right to the River Trail or left to the Schuylkill River Trail - Pawlings to Betzwood.

The Tebolt Trail is mostly rough doubletrack. Usually used to finish the Clockwise Quebec loop, it is an ascent from Mill/Quebec Run up to the junction leading to the parking area. The climb is a consistent and there are a few tougher sections but nothing unmanageable. It is also worth noting that there is a stream crossing near the beginning that can be challenging when the water is high.

Tebolt Trail Intersects the Hess Trail near the trailhead parking area. If your hike starts at the parking area, you'll descend the steep section of the Hess Trail, which can be a wake up call because it is moderately steep and rough due to an abundance of small rocks. The junction is reached very quickly. However, it's more likely that you'll end your hike with the Tebolt Trail.
Land Manager:  PA DCR - Promised Land State Park
Land Manager:  PA DCNR Susquehannock State Park
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - French Creek
Gated dirt road access from the Burma parking area to a gas well. Provides access to Spruce Run Trail, Summit Trail, and Beam Run Trail.

This trail runs between the White Blaze Trail at the top of the North Park Pool area to the Underpass Trail and Ball Field Hill trails towards the bottom of the hill.

The trail passes over pine soft and dirt trail and is easily navigable when heading up or down the hill. This route follows white and orange blazes.

The Snow Shoe Rail Trail is a scenic route along an old railroad corridor. Although not technically challenging, the rough and bumpy ballast surface can make it tough going at times. Fall is a particularly beautiful time of year to be on the trail when the leaves are changing.

The route can be done as a point-to-point or as an out-and-back, as there are multiple access points along the trail.

Starting at the intersection with Laurel Run Road, the trail drops and then climbs, eventually intersecting with an unnamed trail and then the Shingletown Gap/Mid State Trail.  Sand Spring Trail then drops again and intersects with Charcoal Flats and Lower Trail before climbing again to its terminus with Bald Knob Ridge.

What makes this trail difficult at times is the overgrowth of grass in sections that prevent proper footing.

The trail starts at the park office under cover of a planted pine forest, which is very cool and has very soft footing. It starts with a gentle climb before crossing a cinder road. Cross the cinder road onto a grass road. The trail turns almost immediately to the right - if you arrive at an oil well, turn around and locate the trail. 

From here, the trail becomes more grass covered and includes several climbs and descents. You'll pass the Orchard Trail, noted by trail signage, to stay on Hunter Ridge make the sharp right. The next trail you'll come to is about a mile later, Adams Run Trail.

trail_name: Carpenter Trail - Yellow Blaze Black Dot
description:
This wide doubletrack trail follows the Yellow Blaze/Black Dot markings and connects from the area across Pierson Run Road to the soccer fields below Centerview Drive. This is a wide doubletrack and is often used by joggers, hikers, and dog walkers so please look out for your fellow trail users here. 

This is a great way to access the Ski Lodge Loop - Yellow Blaze and there are many access trails between this and the Yellow Blaze Red Dot trail if you're looking for a more rolling singletrack experience. 

You can also connect from here to the Orange Blaze trails and the Wave Pool Trail - Orange Blaze via the Yellow Blaze Red Dot and Yellow Blaze Brown Dot Trail.
This trail rewards with beautiful Pennsylvania woodlands as well as views of the Allegheny River as you trek through mixed hardwoods and evergreens along the rim of the gorge.

One of two trails that head to Lake Chestnut and connect to Boulder Line trail. The loop at the end is pleasant when taken in either direction. The section out to the lake is smooth and wide. As wraps around the lake, sometimes joining Boulder Line Trail for a short stretch, it has some rocks and roots and a little climbing. The trail configuration is a "lollipop" loop or you can exit on Lake Chestnut trail, which will also bring you back to the road where you started.

For the most part this is paved, but in some areas in the Alan Seeger Natural Area the pavement is breaking up and is in worse condition than some of the dirt roads. Long Mountain Trail dumps out onto this road if you are hiking in the downhill direction.

A point to point trail with many connectors to the ball fields, this trail takes you through some beautiful forest. Side trails include the X-Country trail and the Hollow Oak Trail. Notably the Hollow Oak Trail can be used to connect to Hollow Oak Land Trust's Montour Woods Conservation Area property.

This trail is a great example of the varied terrain available in the area. This trail is rolling, and visitors will enjoy moving through the combination of forest and open field.

A long climb followed by an equally long downhill makes this a really fun loop.  Starting at the end of the Hartwood Acres Red Loop you can jump across the paved road/walk lane and follow the blue blazes. 

The trail starts with a long climb, about 0.75 miles long.  It's not steep but noticeable.  At the far end of the trail, you'll make a hard turn that brings you back downhill on the south side and intersects itself a tenth of a mile north of the start.

Hawkeye Ski Trail is a loop through hemlock and spruce forests. The route dips in, crosses, and climbs out of Rock Run Creek. The first three miles feature a steady descent when taking the loop in a counterclockwise direction, and you'll want to be sure to save enough energy for the last climb which is just shy of a mile long.

Cables General Store in Uniondale is an absolute gem!

Start north from the parking lot up a gravel road. Follow the gravel road to the end where it then becomes a doubletrack/dirt road down into the woods. Wander your way up and around the hollow and enjoy the scenery. 

Once to the intersection, be sure to check the signs as there are a few options. To stay on Cheryl's Trail, head west for a little more climbing as you begin to loop back around. It is all downhill back to the intersection. At the intersection, head back to the parking lot or hike some more trails.

This is a continuation of the main, red-blazed loop. It has several rocky sections, but is not as difficult as other trails nearby, the trail can be used as a bypass or shortcut for the hillier Switchback Trail, Ridge Trail,  Boulder Trail and Boulder Bypass, which it connects to.

Done in the direction shown, it's a slight upward grade. The trail starts as a smooth, straight section off the end of the Lower Spanky, then crosses an old abandoned road and a powerline cut, and enters a wooded, stone-armored section. After picking up the Boulder Bypass, it enters a swampy area, with corduroy and bridges to get through the wet parts. The trail ends at Constitution Drive, where you can continue on Sticker Hell across the street.

The Red Loop starts where the Hartwood Acres Yellow Loop leaves off.  Following the red/white blazes, you'll partially circumnavigate one of the many little hills in the park.  Part of this loop is attached to the Green Loop.  The trail ends with an uphill back to the paved road/walk lane.
As of January 2018, the easiest access is to park at the dead end of Hay Creek Road south of Rustic Park and hike down the abandoned portion of the road.

The Deer Path Trail is a short trail through the woods with nice views of the lake. You can start your hike at either end as there is a parking lot on both sides. There is little to no elevation change and several small bridge crossings. Be sure to watch your footing as there are lots of roots.

Starting at the parking lot along the north shore of Chapman State Park lake, Adams Run Trail starts up a slight incline into the woods following along Adams Run. At the fork in the trail, take the left onto what looks like a tall grass path (right takes you onto Hunters Ridge Trail). The path rises up a small slope leaving behind the grass.

The trail winds its way around the hillside, providing mostly manageable trail with a few instances of tall grasses obstructing view of foot placement. Hikers will pass by a "trail" of sorts at a distinctive intersection. There are two options; straight takes you to the connector trail, and right keeps hikers on Adams Run Trail. Adams Run Trail begins its descent to the game land dirt road. To connect back with the campground, make a left on the dirt road and look for the Lowlands Trail sign on the right.

Note: The connector trail is a grass hillside with yellow blazes, but no trail visible. Moreover, the hillside is a water runoff, making it sloppy and not very easy to hike.

trail_name: Plum Creek Trail to Dark Hollow Meadow
description: Watch out for knotweed.

Start at the intersection with Little Flat Tower Road and drop steeply the entire way.  At the end, you'll intersect with Laurel Run Road where there is a small parking area and an intersection with Three Bridges Trail.
Runs from East Run Road, just west of 5 Points intersection, to Pine Flat Road. Originally a log tram route. Drivable doubletrack, also open to ATV's. Standing water during wetter seasons.
Pipeline connects the east and west sides of Clear Creek State Park. The route is easygoing with one steep climb/descent from the River Trail.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest

From the parking area at Pawlings Farm/Walnut Hill Barn, head south.  When the road turns west, continue south towards a No Biking sign.  You'll be on an unnamed path through the wetlands.  

Turn to the right at the first intersection (before reaching the large seasonal pond in front of you).  Follow this path as it wanders through the remains of a large retention bond built to hold back coal laden sediments dredged from the Schuylkill River in the late 1940's-early 1950's. The trail will work its way back out to the gravel road portion of the Commissary Trail near Sullivan Road and the River Trail.  This basin was designed to hold water, and thus the trail can become muddy (and flooded at times).

Start at the intersection with the Mid State Trail at the fire tower and old cabin. Stay left near the fire pit but don't go as far as Little Flat Tower Road.  At the Y-intersection, stay left.  

The trail will wind around as you descend to the intersection with Laurel Run Road. As the trail approaches Laurel Run Road it makes a sharp left. At this point you can see a small spring off to the right of the trail.

The trail is a pleasant 1.5-mile hike through a mixed hardwood forest. It begins at a dirt road with a confusing name. Some maps refer to it as Biesecker Gap Rd., others Snowy Mountain Rd., and another as Forest Rd. The trail is approximately 200 feet north of where the AT crosses the road. Look for a yellow gate. There is a small pull off parking area nearby. The trail is mostly rolling hills of hard pack dirt with areas that are rocky. In mid-summer, the exposed areas were covered in knee-high weeds. There are no overlooks or other notable sights. The trail ends at the intersection of Hayes Run Haul Rd.

Starting near the Polo Field, the trail can be accessed from the Gravel Path, just past the Gas Well Path, or from Gas Well Path just 75 feet into the trail. If accessing from Gas Well Path, a fenced off area will be immediately alongside the trail. The Spruce Trail starts at the corner of the Gas Well Path and the fence, running between the fence and a row of underbrush. The trail is mostly dirt, with a few rocks or roots, but there are several locations prone to turning to mud. The trail is also a mix of single and doubletrack, although it is primarily doubletrack.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Little Buffalo State Park

Weiser State Park is a densely forested gem, and this trail takes advantage of the beautiful surroundings. The trail is a gravel road, and provides the perfect surface for casual outings. Additionally, this trail can be used to get to the Doc Smith Trail and Rattling Creek Trail .

Like Brocker Trail, Rankin Trail can be used for various loop options when hiking the area. It's good in either direction, but the descent from Hess Trail is particularly recommended. It runs along an old rough doubletrack with some small ledgy bits and rocks. In this direction it terminates at the beautiful Mill Run Trail.
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest

Start at the intersection with Sand Spring and head due west.  This trail parallels Roaring Run, very closely at first but then less so as it continues. Watch your footing, but generally this is an easy trail. At the end, it turns into State College Overlook which takes you up to a ridge with a view of State College.

At just over a mile long, the Heffern Run Trail is a connector from Forest Road to Tom's Run Road. This quiet and scenic trail is a gradual downhill in this direction and heads through the woods which provide a sense of solitude even though you are paralleling Forest Road.
The trail make a fairly steep uphill grade from the Pumphouse Trail parking lot to the Martz Trail.

This easy-to-follow trail begins as an old doubletrack logging road. After approximately one mile, it passes through a clearing that has been dubbed a wild turkey habitat project before re-entering the forest in a singletrack fashion. Shortly, the trail begins to climb, reaching gradients in the 8-12% range for three quarters of a mile until it tops out in a clear-cut/nuke zone that is particularly unattractive. 

The last stretch is on a gravel road to the terminus at Rattlesnake Run Road. I took it in January and the winter views were nice, if unspectacular. We incorporated this trail within a longer hike starting at Camp Penn. If you'd like to replicate our route, the trails used included Reservoir Hill, Royer Hollow, Stone Quarry, Corner 10, High Rock Road Bypass, Old Green Ridge Road, Columbia Gas Pipeline and the Appalachian Trail.

This trail begins at the parking area next to the concession stand and beach. The first half of this trail is on a boardwalk that, while nice, could use some minor maintenance much like the other boardwalks in the park. In this section, it passes over a beaver dam and its reservoir.  

There are many butterflies and dragonflies in this area.  After it leaves the boardwalk, the trail follows a gravel path that is very well maintained. Finally, it transitions into the grass and passes a group of cabins until it meets its terminus at Cabin Colony Road.

The Lake Trail is perfect for an easygoing hike through Hibernia County Park that ends at the scenic, 90-acre Chambers Lake. Although most of the Lake Trail is around a 5% grade, it is wheelchair accessible. The stone-dust surface extends from Hibernia Mansion Parking Lot to the scenic overlook near the fishing pier.
A short trail through the woods which drops from the ridge (traversed by the Mid State Trail) down to Laurel Run Road.

Short trail connecting Bear Meadows Loop to Wampler Road.  Starting from Bear Meadows Loop heading south, hikers will go up a moderate incline to an intersection with section 8 of the Mid State Trail. About 25 yards after the intersection is a smaller campsite with a fire ring on a charcoal flat.  

The descent down to Wampler Road is generally pretty thick with Mountain Laurel. There are a few other potential campsites on small charcoal flats, though not as large as the first campsite closest to the Mid State Trail. About 0.25 miles before Wampler Road is Gettis Spring to the west of the trail.

This trail is an open, but seldom used, dirt road, also known as J. E. Miller Road, that extends from Laurel Summit Road to the intersection with Silvermine but is gated just beyond. Beyond the gate the trail is a more distinctly doubletrack with grass down the middle.  

Part way between the gate and Bobcat Trail is a link connecting this trail to the Wolf Rocks Trail, which would allow you to hike the easier middle section of Wolf Rocks Trail in combination with Spruce Flats Trail rather than the road. If Wolf Rocks Trail is your sole destination, there is a parking area adjacent to the beginning intersection.  If you are using this trail to access the south segment of Black Bear Trail, the intersection there is indistinct.  

This trail also provides access to the only designated State Forest campsite (#1) in the Park. Reservation info can be found at  apps.dcnr.state.pa.us/fores… .

It is a county park, so there are no parking fees. There are plenty of newly constructed restrooms throughout the park.

Connects from the rear of the warming hut, crosses Spruce Run Trail and ends at the southern leg of Spruce Run Trail near the Burma parking.

The north end starts as bouldery descending to the Spruce Run stream crossing.  The trail is much smoother to its crossing of Spruce Run Trail. Short dogleg on Spruce and turn left into the driveway to a cottage and veer right to begin a rocky gradual climb before leveling off.

The south segment between the Spruce intersections is best in the northbound direction.

From the Carriage Park Apartments enter the woods. This section begins to gradually descend in a more shaded section toward the park boundary, before turning east and rapidly descends into the valley between the two hills, over a creek, and up the other side.

Keep straight at the next intersection and left at the one soon after to circle around a small knoll and end on the Ridge Connector.

This trail runs along Trout Run in a flood plain, offering several options at several locations to take the high trail or the stream trail. The surface itself is mostly even, with not much in the way of obstacles, outside of stream crossings.  Several other trails, Beaver Dam Path, Swamp Hill and Towhee Trail, spur off, all of which head straight uphill over tough terrain and steep ascents.

Access is available at Fern Hollow Road and the Gas Well Path.
This trail around the lower shoreline of Black Moshannon Lake has a dam and a swimming beach.  There are picnic tables and benches nearby.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCR - Promised Land State Park
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation

The trail can be accessed from the Gravel Path at the top of the hill or from Trout Run from the bottom. Starting from the top of the hill, the trail starts out with a gentle slope over mostly dirt singletrack. The Towhee-Gas Well Connector (not blazed on trail, but identifiable by sudden 10 foot rise in the trail and a tree on the downhill slope side) is the marker for the steepest downhill section of the trail. From this point to the bottom, the trail can be sloppy with leaves, mud, loose rock, and a few roots.

Begin this trail near the concert stage and sledding hill looking for yellow blazes to the southeast.  There are many off-shoots along all trails in Hartwood Acres, but stick to the blazes and you'll end up back where you started.

The trail is typical Western PA dirt singletrack.  This trail is more sweeping than undulating.

This is the uppermost loop of Bird Park, and it is accessible from other trails in the park or from the parking lot on Beadling Road. The trail mostly works its way along the hillsides. There is varied growth and terrain to keep it interesting the whole time.

At the time of year when we tried this trail, it was hard to follow the trail through the meadow because the meadow was mowed down. Maybe at other times of year, the meadow grass is taller and the trail path is mowed and easy to find. There are some gradual hills and some wooded areas.

Starting from Spruce Run and heading downhill, the trail immediately begins to drop off from the hilltop. The trail has plenty of exposed roots and fallen trees across the trail. The last very little bit of trail becomes extremely steep, and at the crest of this drop off there is an opportunity to look out across Trout Run, especially in fall.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest

This trail connects from the Rock-n-Ridge to Crist Ridge Connector to Rock-n-Ridge #2 to Rock-n-Ridge #4.  

While this trail can be traveled both directions, this is mostly used as an uphill. It starts along a creek as a scenic mixture of doubletrack. After crossing a bridge it climbs as a mix of single and doubletrack that can be loose and wet. 

After a challenging uphill rocky section, the trail turns into singletrack again before a right turn leads up a steep gravel road climb. There will be an intersection on a left turn that is not apparent on the map. Heading to the right will continue to Rock-n-Ridge #4 and left will come out at the Group Camp.

This wooded trail has some muddy spots, but they are usually easy to get around. It is located in the dense forest right off the lake and connects to the West Overlook Trail, which goes directly to the lake.

The Purple Loop is tough to access as it resides beyond park roads at the southern section of the park.  One way to reach it is to take the Green Loop, which shares a short section with the Purple Loop.

The Purple Loop trail is well-groomed and well blazed.  You can expect an easy hike with minimal climbing.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR Susquehannock State Park

The west branch of Black Bear connects the south branches of Black Bear Trail and Silvermine Trail, while avoiding the easy dirt road connection provided by Rector-Eddie Road. It's a challenging rocky trail from start to finish.
Start at the intersection with the Mid State Trail and drop the entire length of this rocky trail to its intersection with Laurel Run Road.
Land Manager:  Milton S. Hershey Medical Center
The Hay Road Trail goes through hardwood forest between Moshannon Road and Black Moshannon Lake, crossing the Seneca Trail and the Indian Trail on the way.
Land Manager:  City of Pittsburgh, PA - Parks
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Jacobsburg Environmental Education Center
Mildly steep. Overlook where you can see the lake at the top.
Land Manager:  NLT - Bear Creek Preserve

From the Soccer Field Parking area head southwest through the field towards Pierson Run Road. The trail will be on your right. The trail winds it's way along the contours surrounding the soccer fields. Numerous trails branch off to the soccer fields. The trail ends at Centerview Drive, a partially paved and gravel road that is NOT open to traffic and leads to the baseball fields. Directly across the road from the outlet of the trail is the start of the Blue Trail.

Use Brocker Trail for various loop options. Brocker Trail connects upper Tebolt Trail to Mill Run Trail. It is excellent singletrack, good in either direction. If taken from Tebolt, the trail is a moderate descent pretty much the whole way.  The trail is often predominately leaf-covered and seems less used than others (overall most of the trails in this area seem little used).

Starting from the Southern point of the trail, the yellow-blazed Quehanna Trail West Cross Connector leaves the Quehanna Trail at Wallace Mine Rd., where it follows the road for a little while before making a left and meandering through the forest. After crossing Caledonia Pike, the trail skirts around the Shaggers Inn Shallow Water Impoundment. 

Take a short detour down the road to check out the small lake.  After crossing Shaggers Inn Rd., the trail follows an old logging road before turning back into singletrack leading to a nice overlook before heading down a steep mountain.  The trail ends at the base of the mountain on Little Medix Rd. where it rejoins the orange-blazed Quehanna Trail.  

The West Cross Connector can be used to create a 19 mile Western loop of the Quehanna Trail for a nice overnight backpacking trip or long day hike. It can also be used to create an Eastern loop of the Quehanna Trail, which would cut off approximately 12 miles worth of hiking.

At Junction of Maple Springs Road and Stone Manse Dr, the trail slips into the woods on right side of Stone Manse Dr.  After following the small stream the trail ascends the hill paralleling the golf course.  At Maple Springs Dr., turn left up the hill before turning right onto Brownsville Rd.  (Caution at this intersection).  After 0.10 Mile make a left turn onto Ridge Rd continue up Ridge Road to an intersection with Sunny Slopes.  At this intersection, you'll hike through a gravel pull off that tapers into singletrack.  Follow this through the woods down to Police Station and SP High School.
Land Manager:  Milton S. Hershey Medical Center
Land Manager:  PA DCNR Susquehannock State Park

The Lake Shore Trail is considered the most scenic trail in Little Pine State Park, running along the lake into the upper valley of the park.

Using the Little Pine Creek dam as its starting point, the route heads out across to the other side and then turns left. Here, it enters a wooded area along the lakeshore. There's a bit of a climb followed by a descent, taking you to the nesting area of a pair of bald eagles.

Keeping your eyes peeled, continue on to a beautiful valley beyond the lake. You'll arrive at the loop section of the hike here. Either way, there's a climb and descent. As you make your way around, you'll be in a mix of open areas and wooded forest.

Once you've completed the loop, head back toward the dam on rolling terrain that climbs back to the beginning of the hike.

This trail is described on the DCNR Michaux Map as a drivable trail. The trail/logging road was doubletrack and easy to follow. When used in mid-summer, the sunny areas had tall weeds. There was also logging near the County Line Trail.
Land Manager:  NLT - Bear Creek Preserve
Rocky and sometimes wet when you get to the climb/loop area. Stay on the flat trail along Plum Creek if you aren't looking for elevation.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Bald Eagle State Forest

The northern section connecting Lippos to Bill Alberts Trails is a wide singletrack, level and smoothly graded for groomed cross country skiing.  It creates a bigger easy loop connecting Lippos Trail, Bill Alberts Trail, and Loop Trail of the areas upper plateau. A downhill on the south end is cobbley but still negotiable. 

From the bottom of the hill to Locust Camp Road, the trail is generally smooth and flat singletrack. The trail makes a sharp left on the near side of Locust Camp Road and continues on a slightly wider, flat, wet grade to the Burma parking area.
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  Township of Upper St. Clair

As with the Loop Trail, this section is a wide singletrack, level and smoothly graded for groomed cross country skiing, but is a good introduction to hiking in the woods.

Start/end points shown on map and profile are arbitrary.
Land Manager:  Milton S. Hershey Medical Center

Coyote is an old-school western PA-style trail with undulating switchbacks. There are wide banked turns and a natural stone bridge. The bottom of the trail mellows out as it heads down to intersect with the Deer Trail and Herron.

This gravel forest road will link you from Coopers Gap into the village of Milroy. While nothing spectacular in and of itself, this road can be used to access more of the great singletrack that the area has to offer. 

This section from where No Name Trail intersects the trail has been a part of the State Forest 101 for several years. 

Access Info:
Off Old Rte 322, Conklin Rd or Spruce Mtn Rd.
Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Forbes State Forest

This trail brings hikers from Chappells Field Trail to Rock-n-Ridge #2. 

This is a short but fun section with a set of rock steps. It is only done in the downhill direction, west to east.
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation

This is an tougher trail beginning and ending on Black Bear, typically done northbound. It starts with a short rocky climb after crossing a notched log at the trail entrance leads to a level route over small rounded boulders leading to the descent over/through the rock outcrop. The final stretch is through a high rock and narrow crevice

Beam Run Trail provides an intermediate connection between the northern section of Black Bear Trail North to Spruce Run Trail, near the end of Burma Trail. This trail starts on Black Bear Trail North, north of the starting point of Rocky Gap.  A recently constructed stub connects Black Bear Trail to Laurel Summit Road. It is typically wet along the near side of the road. A parking area for one or two vehicles is located on the opposite side of the road.

Beam Run Trail descends from the parking spot along a wider corridor that is poorly drained at the upper end. Although the trail may appear to continue straight as you pick up speed on the descent, it takes a sudden sharp left turn, onto narrower singletrack. The turn is not as difficult to see coming the other direction.  

The rest of the trail is rocky, consisting mainly of rounded embedded boulders rather than the smaller more abrupt stones encountered elsewhere.

This trail follows White Blaze Blue Dot markings starting above the log house just off of Outer Trail - Gravel Road. The trail continues in front of the large barn uphill from the log cabin and comes out on Pierson Run Road. Cross the road and look to your left about 200 feet up for the entry to the Orange Trail. 

You can connect directly from the White Blaze Trail heading south to go towards the Wave Pool Trail - Orange Blaze trail or take it north and wind around down to the Blue Blaze Trail. Either way you decide to go, this trail is easily navigable with one climb or descent.
Follow this trail northwest from the lower gravel parking lot for a very slightly climb. At the end of the baseball field fence hang a right to drop into Heron.

Trail #14 bisects Trail #13, going over the top of the hill that Trail #13 circles. The northern leg of the trail has some short, steep parts with a large log and rock to climb over. It then follows a ridge line along the border of a deer pen for a short distance before descending to meet up with Trail #13 again. There is also a spur trail (Trail #14A) that cuts down from the ridge to the eastern part of Trail #13.
Like many trails at Denton Hill State Park, this is a wide trail following ski slopes. The weeds can be quite high (4+ feet) during the summer, so wear pants and insect repellent.

Accessible from the Blue Blaze Trail this loop is blazed with a black dot and will be on your left if you are coming from the baseball fields. 

Also accessible from the gravel road running from the baseball fields to the log cabin. Turn left at the first trail opening. You'll have 4 options here. The furthest left will follow the Blue Trail back to the ball fields. The furthest right is the Blue Blaze and Blue-Red trails. The two trails in the middle are either end of this loop.

trail_name: Buck Run Road / Hemlock Trail Connector
description: Land Manager:  PaDCNR - Laurel Hill State Park
Welcome Mat is a beginner level trail with two bridges, two gentle switchbacks, and an introduction to banked turns. It also features a stick fort!
Like many trails at Denton Hill State Park, this is a wide trail following ski slopes. The weeds can be quite high (4+ feet) during the summer, so wear pants and insect repellent.

This trail is a quick loop around John Doctor Field, part of the Bird Park Trail Loops. The trail acts as a connector to many side trails which lead to the surrounding neighborhood. Expect a few fun descents on this shaded singletrack in the thick of the woods.
Nice hike. Lots of big trees. Distinct lack of beavers however.

Moderate hike through the pine tree natural area.

Starting from Fern Hollow Road and ending at Pipeline Pass, this trail heads straight uphill over rocky terrain. The trail also connects Trout Run and crosses Bog Run. While the trail is consistently around the 10% to 15% grade, there are several locations where the grade drops closer to 5% giving your legs a short breather.

Nettle is aptly named for its massive acreage of stinging nettles. The good news is that volunteers work hard to keep the trail open.

From Deer Trail it travels some some long sweeping turns before encountering a large dirt ramp. After a short, easy climb, you meet up with Herron.
Land Manager:  Chester County, PA - East Bradford Township Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  PA DCNR Erie Bluffs State Park
Tick repellent! Sections gets overgrown quickly in summer.

Sharp Valley starts at the Activities Trail, meets the bottom of the Light Trail, and extends uphill across South Camp Road, heading west. 

It contains a series of railroad-tie erosion steps with one-foot drops before following a creek down through the valley. It intersects with North Valley, Big Timber, and Spring Trails and ends at Hammer Creek Road.
This section of trail added to Memorial Trail makes a nice gentle flat loop at the top of the park.

Herron trail starts as a gently rolling contour trail before it drops down into the Jacks Run Valley. Part way down there is a large stump mound on the left. At that point, the trail turns and drops sharply to the left, then immediately turns sharp and quick to the right. 

The lower portions of the trail have some features for mountain bikers, but they are easy to go around. At a climbing left, the singletrack junctions with Nettle. Continuing on Heron, complete the sweep left, then turn right. At the end, you'll meet up with Deer (a left turn) and Coyote (straight across).
Depending on direction, this short trail is either a fast descent or short climb at the southern end of the park.

This is a short and flat multi-use trail on the shore overlooking the East Branch Clarion Reservoir.  It begins at the north end of the parking lot for the boat ramp by the East Branch Dam which is controlled by the Army Corp of Engineers. As it leaves the dam area it becomes a very thin strip of Elk State Park.  

There are private homes to the left and private docks to the right. It is dotted with benches, grills, and picnic tables. The entire trail offers great views of the lake and of the dam.  The terminus of the trail is an overlook at a bend in the shoreline with a grill and picnic table.

As a portion of the southwest network of trails, this area is a bit of a spaghetti maze. It's fun to hike around though - you won't get lost because the area is actually quite small and contained. This is a great place for youngsters to get their energy out!
This is an easy doubletrack with roots and a bridge crossing. There are several offshoots along this trail that you can use to explore the park.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Jacobsburg Environmental Education Center

The central section of Black Bear starts from a sometimes difficult to spot location along Rector-Eddie Road (J.E. Miller Road) and extends northward to a point where it dumps out on Laurel Summit Road. The northern section of Black Bear, signed as Expert branches off to the left just before reaching the road. The easiest north-south connection requires bypassing Black Bear Trail North and using approximately 0.4 mile of Laurel Summit Road (open) to Locust Camp Road (gated).

The central section consists of level singletrack with a few rounded embedded boulders. A light rocky section is located near the intersection with Hemlock Trail and the Black Bear Trail West.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest
Nice loop around the Crooked Run Campground. You can get on and off in several spots!
Short loop that can be connected with some other neighboring trails.

Beginning at the Expert sign just off the Black Bear connection to Laurel Summit Road, the trail rolls along a generally level route. It includes one required boulder obstacle. 

One rocky section follows before reaching the Rocky Gap Trail intersection where the trail becomes nearly continuous rocks to Locust Camp Road.  An unsigned intersection to the right along this last segment is an extension of Beam Run Trail.

As a portion of the southwest network of trails, this area is a bit of a spaghetti. This spur connects with other portions, but my GPS went out (feel free to update!). It does lots of looping and into areas that don't seem to EVER dry out! Be ready for some wet feet, especially if there has been rain recently.

Though there are a lot of intersecting trails, it's easy to stay oriented.
Land Manager:  NLT - Peacedale Preserve
Land Manager:  Bucks County, PA - Parks and Recreation
Land Manager:  Milton S. Hershey Medical Center

Violet Trail may be accessed from Spring Hollow Trail or Goldenrod Trail. This is not an overly challenging trail in terms of climb; though, the trail does contain large roots running perpendicular to the trail at several locations, so keep an eye out.

Beginners following this trail from Rector-Eddie Road can turn right onto the easier middle section of Wolf Rocks Trail or turn left onto the intermediate section. Those looking for a bit more of a challenge can continue through on Hobblebush Trail or Wolf Rocks Loop.

This trail starts behind the Frick Park Bowling Greens with a quick downhill. Use caution and watch out for other trail users as the bottom of the dip is an intersection with two other wide trails. The trail then climbs up and back out to Hawthorne Trail.

This trail climbs from Rock-n-Ridge to Group Camp. 

This trail is nicknamed "The Punisher" due to the difficulty in climbing it. It can be done both directions but is typically done uphill as a challenging climb. It is a scenic singletrack until, 0.75 mile up, it makes a right turn and becomes very loose, washed out and steep. It comes out at the Group Camp right below the pool.

Midway along the eastern edge of the parking lot the singletrack, the trail will begin again to continue your gradual climb up to Interstate Trail.  Both singletrack sections are rocky in places.

It begins with a gradual climb through pronounced rounded boulders to a rockier climb up the outcrop. The trail is the fairly level to its intersection with Black Bear Trail.  Watch for an optional line to the right that will take you over a couple wooden bridges spanning some deep gaps between boulders.

This trail has a few rocks and roots, but is easy to travel with little grade. It connects Fulton to Fleming, with Friends, Stone Mason 1, and Stone Mason 2 along the way. The wide trail provides easy travel in both directions.

It's best to enter this trail from the east off of Bronson and end at the junction of Spring and Fleming. This will give you a mostly downhill experience with a short climb at the end. There are a few root obstacles, but it is a relatively easy trail.

From the game lands parking lot, head straight out the path at the end of the parking lot. At the trails end you can choose to connect with the Horseshoe Trail: Eagle Rock to Ash Lane or continue straight.
A simple connector that spans from the Ranger's Station to the main pavilion. This trail intersects with the bottom of Light Trail and Sharp Valley Trail (Lower).
